MINUTES OF PROCEEDINGS - Telephonic Motion Hearing held on 4/29/2020 before Chief Judge Miranda M. Du. Crtrm Administrator: Peggie Vannozzi; Pla Counsel: James Bopp, Jr., David O'Mara; Def Counsel: Gregory Zunino and Craig Newby (for Defendant Secretary of State), Herbert Kaplan (for Defendant Washoe County Registrar of Voters); Marc Elias, Courtney Elgart, Abha Khanna, Bradley Schraeger and Daniel Bravo (for Defendant Internvenors); Court Reporter: Kathy French; Time of Hearing: 10:03 AM - 11:30 AM; Courtroom: 5; Also present by telephone: Nevada Sectary of State Barbara Cegavske with deputies Wayne Thorley and Scott Anderson and Washoe County Registrar of Voters Deanna Spikula. The Court advises counsel that it has reviewed the briefs as to Plaintiff's Motion for Preliminary Injunction (ECF No. 2,) Defendants' responses (ECF Nos. [25, 28, 27 -1) the declaration of Deanna Spikula (ECF No. 25,) and Plaintiffs' reply (ECF No. 43 .) The Court has no need for counsel to address the COVID-19 issue. Mr. Bopp, Mr. Zunino, Mr. Kaplan and Ms. Khanna present argument. Mr. Kaplan asks the Court to allow Washoe County to supplement its response. The Court will allow Washoe County to supplement its response on a very narrow issue. The supplement must be filed by the end of the day. Mr. Bopp presents Plaintiffs' reply argument and answers questions posed by the Court. Mr. Kaplan answers a question posed by the Court. The Court will not authorize any additional supplementation other than as to the narrow issue identified above. Plaintiff's motion for preliminary injunction (ECF No. 2 ) is taken under advisement. (no image attached) (Copies have been distributed pursuant to the NEF - PAV) (Entered: 04/29/2020)

case_data.summary:
This case challenged the Nevada Secretary of State's and County Administrators' plan to conduct an all-mail election for the 2020 primary election in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. Three individual residents of Nevada filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nevada on April 21, 2020.  Plaintiffs sued Nevada's Secretary of State and Washoe County's Registrar of Voters under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, claiming violations under the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution, Article 2, § 1 of the Nevada Constitution, Article I, § 4, Clause 1 of the U.S. Constitution and Article IV, § 4 of the U.S. Constitution. Plaintiffs were represented by private counsel and True the Vote, Inc. The case was assigned to Chief Judge Miranda M. Du.

Plaintiffs had five key allegations.  First, the all-mail election limited the right to vote by diluting Plaintiffs' votes with illegal votes.  Second, the all-mail election overruled and replaced the Legislature's chosen manner of election invalidating the Plaintiffs' votes for the representatives who decide the manner of elections.  Third, the all-mail election violated the Purcell Principle because it altered election procedures near the date of the election.  Fourth, the all-mail election was not consistent with the manner of election prescribed by the Legislature.  Fifth, the Secretary of State and County Administrators, through the all-mail election, supplanted the Plaintiffs' elected representatives in exercising powers entrusted entirely to the Legislature.  Plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief to prevent the Secretary of State and County Administrators from implementing the all-mail election, as well as attorney's fees.

On March 24, 2020, in response to the Covid-19 pandemic, the Secretary of State of Nevada, announced a plan to conduct an all-mail election for the June 9, 2020 Nevada primary election.  The plan was formulated by the Secretary of State and Nevada's 17 county election officials.  Under the plan, all active registered voters would be mailed an absentee ballot for the primary election.  Voters who were registered at their current address did not have to take further action to receive an absentee ballot, but individuals who were not registered or needed to update their registration information were required to do so in order to receive an absentee ballot. Qualified voters were not active had to submit an Absent Ballot Request Form to the County Clerk/Registrar of Voters in the county where they were registered to vote in order to receive an absentee ballot. Under the Clark County's implementation of the plan, inactive voters would be sent absentee ballots and field registrars would collect sealed ballots from voters.

On April 21, 2020, Plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction reiterating the allegations in their complaint. 

On April 27, Nevada State Democratic Party, DNC Services Corporation/Democratic National Committee, DCCC, Priorities USA, and John Solomon filed a motion to intervene as defendants.  Intervenor-Defendants argued they satisfied the requirements for intervention as a matter of right, and alternatively, the requirements for permissive intervention.  On April 28, 2020, the court granted the Intervenor-Defendants motion to intervene, finding that Intervenor-Defendants satisfied the requirements for intervention as a matter of right and permissive intervention. 

A hearing on Plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction was held on April 29, 2020. On April 30, 2020, the court denied Plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction finding the Plaintiffs did not establish a particularized injury to confer standing to assert their claims, as the alleged injury of dilution of votes from election fraud raised by Plaintiffs was an issue raisable by any Nevada voter and Plaintiffs did not show a causal connection between the alleged injury of vote dilution and the all-mail election plan. Additionally, the court found that even if the Plaintiffs established standing, the Plaintiffs failed to establish the merits of each of their claims.  However, the court deferred resolving the merits to provide the Secretary of State time to assert Eleventh Amendment immunity, if chosen to do so.

Following this denial, on May 11, 2020, Defendants filed a motion to dismiss Plaintiff's complaint for failure to state a claim, arguing that the court, in its April 30, 2020 Order denying Plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, already found Plaintiffs failed to establish the merits of each claim and that the Secretary of State had not subsequently asserted Eleventh Amendment immunity. 

On May 13, 2020, Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint and a second motion for preliminary injunction.  The amended complaint added four additional individual voters and Nevada Right to Life as Plaintiffs, added the Registrar of Voters for Clark County as a defendant, and asserted four claims.  First, the all-mail election violated the fundamental right to vote by direct disenfranchisement from the sudden surge in mail-in ballots that would bring late, never-arriving, lost, or delayed ballots, in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution.  Second, the all-mail election violated the fundamental right to vote by vote-dilution disenfranchisement by allowing an influx of illegal votes through the sidestepping of statutory safeguards designed to protect against voting fraud, in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution.  Third, the all-mail election sought to conduct the Primary election in a manner not authorized by the Nevada Legislature and contrary to the Legislature's chosen manner of elections, in violation of Article I, § 4, Clause 1 of the U.S. Constitution. Fourth, Clark County's plan to send mail-in ballots to all registered voters and to allow collection of ballots violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Plaintiffs' second motion for preliminary injunction reiterated the allegations in their amended complaint.

Subsequently, on May 19, 2020, Intervenor-Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the Plaintiffs amended complaint arguing Plaintiffs lacked standing and failed to state a claim.  As to the standing point, Intervenor-Defendants argued that the disenfranchisement claim could not be connected to the Defendants' decision to proactively mail ballots to voters, that Plaintiffs claim of injury of dilution of votes from election fraud could be raised by any Nevada voter, and that Plaintiffs' claim under the Elections Clause of the U.S. Constitution does not create a private right of action to enforce state law.  As to the failure to state a claim point, Intervenor-Defendants argued that the U.S. Constitution does not provide relief for Plaintiffs claims, and that Plaintiffs claim that Clark County's plan to send mail-in ballots to all voters (inactive and active) and to send county-approved ballot harvesters to collect ballots violated the right to vote and the equal-protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment was already foreclosed by controlling Ninth Circuit precedent. 

On May 21, 2020, the court found that a hearing on Plaintiff's second motion for preliminary injunction was unnecessary and denied Defendants' motion to dismiss Plaintiffs' first complaint as moot in light of the filing of Plaintiffs' amended complaint.  On May 27, 2020, the court denied Plaintiffs' second motion for preliminary injunction, finding that Plaintiffs still lacked standing to their first three claims, as Plaintiffs' claims could be raised by any Nevada voter and Plaintiffs failed to show that mail-in ballots sent to Nevada voters without requests for absentee ballots would result in direct voter disenfranchisement or disenfranchisement through vote dilution.  Additionally, the court found Plaintiffs were not entitled to equitable relief, as Plaintiffs unreasonably delayed seeking preliminary injunctive relief through their second motion, as they waited fourteen days after the court's first preliminary injunction order and only twenty-six days before the June Primary to file the amended complaint and the second motion for preliminary injunction, and this delay prejudiced Defendants as mail-in ballots had already been sent to many eligible voters. Finally, the court followed the Purcell principle, refusing to alter the mail-in election plan so close to the June primary.

On July 31, 2020, the court dismissed Plaintiffs' case as moot since Plaintiffs could no longer obtain effective relief as the primary election had already occurred on June 9, 2020.
case_data.summary_short: In 2020, three individual residents of Nevada filed this suit against in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nevada.  Plaintiffs alleged that the Secretary of State's and County Administrator's plan to conduct an all-mail election for the June 9, 2020 Nevada primary election violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution, Article 2, ยง 1 of the Nevada Constitution, Article I, ยง 4, Clause 1 of the U.S. Constitution and Article IV, ยง 4 of the U.S. Constitution. On July 31, 2020, the court dismissed Plaintiffs' case as moot since Plaintiffs could no longer obtain effective relief as the primary election occurred on June 9, 2020. The case is closed.

1  12(b)(1) is appropriate if the complaint, considered in its entirety, fails to allege facts on its

4  Although the defendant is the moving party in a motion to dismiss brought under Rule 
5  12(b)(1), the plaintiff is the party invoking the court=s jurisdiction.  As a result, the plaintiff 
6  bears the burden of proving that the case is properly in federal court.  McCauley v. Ford 
7  Motor Co., 264 F.3d 952, 957 (9th Cir. 2001) (citing McNutt v. General Motors Acceptance 
8  Corp., 298 U.S. 178, 189 (1936)).   
9  Federal courts are courts of limited jurisdiction. Owen Equip. & Erection Co. v. 
10  Kroger, 437 U.S. 365, 374 (1978).  AA federal court is presumed to lack jurisdiction in a 
11  particular  case  unless  the  contrary  affirmatively  appears.@  Stock  West,  Inc.  v. 
12  Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation, 873 F.2d 1221, 1225 (9th Cir. 1989).  
13  Thus, federal subject matter jurisdiction must exist at the time an action is commenced. 
14  Mallard Auto. Grp., Ltd. v. United States, 343 F. Supp. 2d 949, 952 (D. Nev. 2004). 
15  The issue of mootness amounts to a facial attack on the AC. AIn a facial attack, the 
16  challenger asserts that the allegations contained in a complaint are insufficient on their 
17  face to invoke federal jurisdiction.โ Safe Air for Everyone v. Myer (โSafe Airโ), 373 F.3d 
18  1035, 1039 (9th Cir. 2004). The court assumes the factual allegations of a complaint to be

that, by themselves, would otherwise invoke federal jurisdiction.@ Safe Air, 373 F.3d at

1  IV. DISCUSSION
2  The Court finds this case is now moot.5 The Court therefore does not consider the
3  other jurisdictional and merits-based arguments for and against dismissal raised in the 
4  partiesโ briefing.    
5  Article III, ยง 2 of the U.S. Constitution states that the federal courts may only 
6  adjudicate โCasesโ and โControversiesโ. See Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 
7  559 (1992); Deakins v. Monaghan, 484 U.S. 193, 199 (1988). By Article III, federal courts 
8  are denied the power to โto decide questions that cannot affect the rights of litigants in the 
9  case before them.โ North Carolina v. Rice, 404 U.S. 244, 246 (1971). The jurisdiction of a 
10  federal court is properly invoked only where litigants have suffered or are โthreatened with, 
11  an actual injury traceable to the defendant and likely to be redressed by a favorable judicial 
12  decision.โ Lewis v. Cont'l Bank Corp., 494 U.S. 472, 477 (1990); North Carolina, 404 U.S. 
13  at 246 (explaining also that courts are not empowered as a matter of jurisdiction to decide 
14  moot questions). That there must be a case or controversy for the exercise of jurisdiction 
15  โsubsists through all stages of federal judicial proceedings, trial and appellate.โ Id. โ[I]t is 
16  not enough that a dispute was very much alive when suit was filed . . . [t]he parties must 
17  continue to have a โpersonal stake in the outcomeโ of the lawsuit.โ Id. at 477โ78 (internal 
18  quotations and citations omitted). 
19  โWhere on the face of the record it appears that the only concrete interest in the 
20  controversy has terminated, reasonable caution is needed to be sure that mooted litigation 
21  is not pressed forward, and unnecessary judicial pronouncements on even constitutional 
22  issues obtained.โ Id. at 480. A case is moot where there remains no present controversy 
23  for which effective relief can be granted. E.g., W. Coast Seafood Processors Ass'n v. Nat. 
24  Res. Def. Council, Inc., 643 F.3d 701, 704 (9th Cir. 2011) (citations omitted); see also 
25  ///
26  5Because the motions to dismiss were filed before the Primary, Defendants and 
Intervenor-Defendants did not have an opportunity to raise the mootness issue. Plaintiffs 
27  raised  the  issue  in  their  response.  (ECF  No.  87  at  3.)  Defendants  and  Intervenor-
Defendants addressed the issue in reply. (ECF No. 88 at 2, n.1; ECF No. 89 at 2โ6.) In 
28  any event, the Court is bound to consider the issue sua sponte. See, e.g., Gator.com Corp. 
v. L.L. Bean, Inc., 398 F.3d 1125, 1129 (9th Cir. 2005) (citation omitted).
5 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 92   Filed 07/31/20   Page 6 of 12
1  Siskiyou Reg'l Educ. Project v. U.S. Forest Serv., 565 F.3d 545 (9th Cir. 2009) (internal 
2  quotation and citations omitted) (โA case becomes moot whenever it loses its character 
3  as a present, live controversy of the kind that must exist if we are to avoid advisory opinions 
4  on abstract propositions of law. The question is not whether the precise relief sought at 
5  the time . . . [the case] was filed is still available. The question is whether there can be any 
6  effective relief.โ) 
7  The Supreme Court has recognized several exceptions to the mootness doctrine, 
8  of which the exception for matters that are capable of repetition while evading review is 
9  immediately relevant.6 See, e.g.,  Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113, 125 (1973);  Honig v. 
10  Doe, 484 U.S. 305, 318โ20 (1988). Plaintiffs argue that exception here, thereby implicitly 
11  conceding that this case is moot under the default mootness doctrine. (ECF No. 87 at 2โ
12  8.) However, the Court finds the capable of repetition while evading review exception does 
13  not preserve the Courtโs jurisdiction over this matter. 
14  Under  the  capable  of  repetition  while  evading  review  exception,  โ[a]  case 
15  otherwise moot will still be heard if it presents an issue that is capable of repetition while 
16  evading review.โ Pub. Utilities Comm'n of State of Cal. v. F.E.R.C., 100 F.3d 1451 (9th 
17  Cir. 1996) (citations omitted). โThis exception applies only in exceptional circumstances.โ 
18  GTE California, Inc. v. Federal Communications Comm'n, 39 F.3d 940, 945 (9th Cir. 1994) 
19  (internal quotation and citation omitted). The exception particularly applies only where two 
20  exceptions have been met: โ(1) the challenged action was in its duration too short to be 
21  fully litigated prior to its cessation or expiration, and (2) there was a reasonable expectation 
22  that the same complaining party would be subjected to the same action again.โ  Murphy 
23  v. Hunt, 455 U.S. 478, 482 (1982) (quotations and citations omitted) (recognizing the
24  exception as articulated in Weinstein v. Bradford, 423 U.S. 147, 149 (1975) (per curiam)).
25  โThe โcapable of repetition, yet evading reviewโ doctrine, in the context of election cases,
26 
6In  addition  to  the  capable  of  repetition  while  evading  review  exception,  the 
27  Supreme Court has recognized the voluntary cessation and collateral consequences 
exceptions. See, e.g., Pub. Utilities Comm'n of State of Cal. v. F.E.R.C., 100 F.3d 1451, 
28  1459โ61 (9th Cir. 1996). The Court has applied an additional mootness exception in class 
action cases. See, e.g., Sosna v. Iowa, 419 U.S. 393, 399โ403 (1975). 
6 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 92   Filed 07/31/20   Page 7 of 12
1  is appropriate when there are โas appliedโ challenges as well as in the more typical case 
2  involving only facial attacks.โ Storer v. Brown, 415 U.S. 724, 737 n.8 (1974); see also 
3  Lawrence v. Blackwell, 430 F.3d 368, 371 (6th Cir. 2005) (โChallenges to election laws 
4  are one of the quintessential categories of cases which usually fitโ the evading-review 
5  prong โbecause litigation has only a few months before the remedy sought is rendered 
6  impossible by the occurrence of the relevant election.โ) (emphasis added). 
7  Plaintiffs essentially argue that the exception is met based on standards that apply 
8  to candidates and voters in election cases. (See generally ECF No. 87 at 2โ8.) However, 
9  each case Plaintiffs materially rely on is inapposite to this case because all those cases 
10  concerned state statutes or other law that would govern successive elections. See, e.g., 
11  Fed. Election Commโn v. Wisconsin Right To Life, Inc., 551 U.S. 449, 449โ50, (2007) 
12  (concerning Section 203 of the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002 (BCRA) that 
13  would in the future apply to the same backout period issue then before the Court): Norman 
14  v. Reed, 502 U.S. 279, 286โ88 (1992) (considering Illinois statute); Intโl Org. of Masters,
15  Mates & Pilots v. Brown, 498 U.S. 466, 473 (1991) (concerning ยง 401(c) of the Laborโ
16  Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 (LMRDA) and noting the section would
17  likely again present an obstacle to a preconvention mailing by respondent ); Storer, 415
18  U.S. at 737 n.8 (โ[T]his case is not moot, since the issues properly presented . . . will
19  persist as the California statutes are applied in future elections.โ); Joyner v. Mofford, 706
20  F.2d 1523, 1527 (9th Cir. 1983) (considering a State of Arizona constitution provision that
21  โcould be tested . . . whenever another elected Arizona official stands for federal officeโ);
22  Libertarian Party of N.M. v. Herrera, 506 F.3d 1303, 1306 n.1 (10th Cir. 2007) (considering
23  New Mexico statute concerning ballot access); Lawrence, 430 F.3d at 369โ72 (involving
24  mootness challenge to Ohio election statute that applied to candidates); Majors v. Abell,
25  317 F.3d 719, 722 (7th Cir. 2003) (concerning Indiana statute).
26  Here, as noted in the Courtโs First Order denying the First PI Motion, in declaring 
27  the Plan the Secretary expressly stated the Plan applies only to the Primary election. (ECF 
28  No. 57 at 2 (referencing ECF No. 1-1).) There is no assertion in the AC that the Plan 
7 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 92   Filed 07/31/20   Page 8 of 12
1  applies to successive Nevada elections. (See generally ECF No. 64.) Accordingly, the 
2  election cases Plaintiffs rely on are materially distinguishable.  
3  Moreover, to be exact, neither of the two requirements of the exception have been 
4  met here.  
5  Plaintiffs contend that the first prongโthe challenged action was in its duration too 
6  short to be fully litigated prior to its cessation or expirationโhas been met because the 
7  Plan and the CC Plan โwere announced in March and April 2020, the initial complaint was 
8  filed April 21, and the June 9 Primary occurred without the opportunity for full review by 
9  this Court, let alone by an appeals court.โ (ECF No. 87 at 4.) The Court disagrees. On the 
10  record here the opportunity for โfull reviewโ by this Court was satisfied because the Court 
11  adjudicated the First PI Motion, and โfull reviewโ by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals was 
12  missed as a result of Plaintiffsโ own dilatory actions. 
13  Intervenor-Defendants point out (ECF No. 89 at 5) that the Ninth Circuit has 
14  explained that: 
15  a  party  may  not  profit  from  the  โcapable  of  repetition,  yet  evading 
reviewโ exception to mootness, where through his own failure . . . he has 
16  prevented an appellate court from reviewing the trial courtโs decision. The 
exception was designed to apply to situations where the type of injury 
17  involved inherently precludes judicial review, not to situations where the 
failure of parties to take certain actions has precluded review as a practical 
18  matter. 
19  Matter of Bunker Ltd. P'ship, 820 F.2d 308, 311 (9th Cir. 1987) (citations omitted). Further, 
20  while election cases may usually fit the evading review standard due to their short duration, 
21  the prong is not met based on mere possibility. See Murphy, 455 U.S. at 482. If it was so 
22  satisfied, then virtually any election provision would be reviewable based on no more than 
23  that they are matters of short duration. 
24  In this case there was nothing inherently preclusive of review. In fact, in its Second 
25  Order the Court expressed surprise at the lack of urgency with which Plaintiffs brought the 
26  AC and their Second PI Motion as well as them not pursuing expedited appellate review 
27  ///
28  ///
8 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 92   Filed 07/31/20   Page 9 of 12
1  instead of filing the substantially duplicative AC.7 (See, e.g., ECF No. 83 at 1 (โPlaintiffsโ 
2  decision to bring the AC at this late hour, as opposed to seeking expedited appellate 
3  review of the Courtโs order . . . regarding their original motion for preliminary injunction . . 
4  . , is confounding and contrary to their position that a quick disposition of this matter is 
5  needed  due  to  the  impending  June  9,  2020  Nevada  primary  election.โ);  id.  (also 
6  recognizing  that  the  AC  and  second  motion  for  preliminary  injunction  โglaringly 
7  repackage[d]  old  arguments  to  achieve  a  different  disposition  without  necessary 
8  justificationโ); id. at 9 (โPlaintiffs waited 14 days after the [First] PI Order was issued and 
9  only 26 days before the June Primary to file the AC and bring the Second PI Motion . . . 
10  Plaintiffs surely have not acted with the alacrity that they claim this case necessitates.โ).)  
11  To be sure, this Court was able to consider both motions for preliminary injunction 
12  within short timeframes with expedited full briefing on both and one hearing for the first 
13  injunction request. The Court could haveโand would haveโalso ordered expedited 
14  briefing to rule on the motions to dismiss. But notably Plaintiffs requested an extension of 
15  time way beyond the Primary dateโJuly 3, 2020โto file their response to the motions to 
16  dismiss  (see  ECF  No.  81).  Plaintiffsโ  own apparent  game  of  wait-and-see  therefore 
17  precluded  further  review  on  the merits before  the Primaryโnot  some  intrinsic  short 
18  duration of election cases generally. Accordingly, Plaintiffs have not satisfied the first 
19  prong under these circumstances. 
20  Even if Plaintiffs may be found to have established prong one, their failure to meet 
21  prong two prevents them from moving forward. As to the second prong, the Supreme Court 
22  has said โthat there must be a โreasonable expectationโ or a โdemonstrated probabilityโ that 
23  the same controversy will recur involving the same complaining party.โ Murphy, 455 U.S. 
24  at 482. (citation omitted and emphasis added). The Court finds no such reasonable 
25  expectation or demonstrated probability in this case. 
26  ///
27 
7Plaintiffs acted contrary to their representation in seeking expedited briefing that 
28  the Court should โissue a ruling with adequate time for [Plaintiffs] to seek emergency stays 
in the Ninth Circuit and U.S. Supreme Court if required.โ (ECF No. 13 at 4.) 
9 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 92   Filed 07/31/20   Page 10 of 12
1  There is no reason beyond supposition at this time to think the Plan (or the CC 
2  Plan) will be valid and apply to future elections. Again, they expressly governed only the 
3  June Primary. The Court recognizes Plaintiffsโ contention that a similar policy will likely be 
4  implemented for future electionsโand particularly the November general electionโdue to 
5  the persistence of the COVID-19 pandemic (and surmising that some other similar health 
6  and public safety crisis will come along). (ECF No. 87 at 6โ8.) Plaintiffs also argue that 
7  the second prong is met even where Plaintiff-candidate, Gladwill, were to not run in future 
8  elections and that Plaintiffsโ intent to run and vote in the future should nonetheless be 
9  inferred from their past conduct of doing these things. (Id. at 4โ6.) But all this is besides 
10  the point. The Plan (and the CC Plan)โas implemented by the Secretary and county 
11  officialsโwere in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and limited to the Primary. The 
12  relief Plaintiffs request in the AC are directly tied to the same. (See ECF No. 64 at 25 
13  (stating, for example โenjoin[]the Secretary and County Administrators to administer the 
14  primary election in accordance with the legislatureโs prescribed manner . . .โ and โenjoin[] 
15  the Clark County Administrators from conducting the primary election in accordance with 
16  the  published  [CC]  Planโ).)  Further,  that  the  Plan  (or  CC  Plan)  at  issue  may  be 
17  prospectively implemented is at best speculative and not supported by the allegations 
18  asserted in the AC.8 
19  ///
20  8In their response, Plaintiffs argue that if the Secretary in fact has authority to 
implement the Plan then the Plan controls through to the November general elections 
21  based on the language in NRS ยง 293.247(1). (ECF No. 87 at 8.) The argument is contrary 
to both the Secretaryโs expressed limitation of the Plan to the Primary and the language 
22 
of ยง 293.247(1). Plaintiffs appear to contort the language of the section to have it say what 
they want it to sayโthat the Plan permanently controls all elections until replaced by other 
23 
regulations. (See id.) But the ordinary reading of ยง 293.247(1) does not support this 
24  contention. See NRS ยง 293.247(1) (โPermanent regulations of the Secretary of State that 
regulate the conduct of a primary, general, special or district election and are effective on 
25 
or before the last business day of February immediately preceding a primary, general, 
special or district election govern the conduct of that election.โ). Not only was the Plan not 
26 
intended to be permanent, it was expressly confined to the Primary. Notably, there is no 
indication on the Secretaryโs website that the November election will be subject to the Plan 
27 
or  be  an  all-mail-in  election.  See  Nevada  Secretary  of  State, 
28  https://www.nvsos.gov/sos/elections/election-information  (last  visited  July  31,  2020). 
10 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 92   Filed 07/31/20   Page 11 of 12
1  Moreover, insomuch as substantively similar provisions may govern future Nevada 
2  elections, those provisions and their conceivable forms are not before this Court for 
3  consideration.9 The Court takes caution within its limited jurisdiction to decide only matters 
4  that are presently and properly before it. Even if the State of Nevada were to, for example, 
5  adopt a statutory scheme for state-wide all-mail-in elections in the future, the Court 
6  imagines that the challenges to such a statute would raise materially different contentions 
7  than which Plaintiffs currently raise. To be sure, Plaintiffsโ current contentions chiefly 
8  revolve around the premise that the Secretary and local county officials acted beyond the 
9  scope of election laws prescribed by the stateโs legislature. Such a theory would likely no 
10  longer be valid where, for example, the stateโs legislature itself vote to adopt a statutory 
11  scheme. If such a time comes, then it is additionally conceivable that different issues and 
12  different (or additional) parties and thus a different controversy will be before the Court for 
13  consideration. For all these reasons, the Court additionally concludes the second prong 
14  has not been met. 
15  In sum, on the record before this Court, even if Plaintiffsโ claims stood on firmer 
16  grounds, Plaintiffs can no longer obtain effective relief because the Primary has already 
17  occurred and the claims and relief Plaintiffs requested are precisely tied to the Primary 
18  and the execution of the Plan (and the CC Plan) as specifically implemented by the 
19  Secretary and local officials in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Court therefore 
20  finds this case moot and will dismiss it on this ground. 
21  ///
22  ///
23  Further, the section lists the types of election in the disjunctive supposing that discrete 
regulations would apply to each. 
24 
9The Court has considered Plaintiffsโ contentions that an all-mail-in election has 
25  been recommended or suggested in Clark County for the upcoming November general 
election and that similar lawsuits are (or may be) in the pipeline. (ECF No. 87 at 7โ8.) But, 
26  as the Court notes infra, there are likely substantive and meaningful distinctions between 
this  lawsuit  as  currently  framed  and  future  lawsuits.  Any  current  Clark  County 
27  recommendation is not a provision, law, or statute creating a ripe issue for review. Any 
question as to how such recommendation affects this case is no more than guess work at 
28  this juncture. Moreover, Clark County specific plans are not tantamount to a statewide 
provision and would also necessarily fall under the Secretaryโs purview for assessment. 
11 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 92   Filed 07/31/20   Page 12 of 12
1  V. CONCLUSION
2  The Court notes that the parties made several arguments and cited to several cases
3  not discussed above. The Court has reviewed these arguments and cases and determines 
4  that they do not warrant discussion as they do not affect the outcome of the issues before 
5  the Court. 
6  It is therefore ordered that this case is now dismissed as moot. The Court therefore 
7  does not consider the merits of Plaintiffsโ claims. 
8  It is further ordered that the pending motions to dismiss (ECF Nos. 71, 77) are 
9  thereby moot and denied accordingly.  
10  The Clerk of the Court is directed to enter judgment in accordance with this order 
11  and close this case. 
12  DATED THIS 31st day of July 2020.

1  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
2  I.  INTRODUCTION 
3  To  diminish  the  spread  of  the  COVID-19  illness,  Secretary  of  State  Barbara 
4  Cegavske  (โSecretary  Cegavskeโ)  and  her  staff  worked  in  partnership  with  Nevadaโs 
5  seventeen local election officials to implement an all-mail primary election for June 9, 
6  2020 (ECF No. 22 at p. 3).  Subsection 4 of NRS 293.213 sets forth the legislative grant of 
7  authority  for  her  do  so  under  the  current  circumstances.  Without  qualification,  this 
8  statutory provision authorizes Nevadaโs state and local election officials to cooperatively 
9  establish โmailing precinctsโ in which registered voters cast their votes by mail.  Despite 
10  Plaintiffsโ arguments to the contrary, Secretary Cegavske was well within her authority, 
11  as lawfully delegated to her by the Nevada Legislature, to approve a statewide all-mail 
  12  primary election.  The motion should be denied.  
13  II.  STATEMENT OF THE CASE 
14  Plaintiffs have filed suit to halt Nevadaโs all-mail primary election in favor of an in-
15  person election.   Plaintiffs allege that they are Nevada registered voters who usually 
16  โvote[] early or on election day in-personโ (ECF No. 1 at p. 3, ยถยถ7-9).  Citing Bush v. Gore 
17  as controlling precedent (ECF No. 2 at pp. 9-11, 14, and 18), Plaintiffs speculate that their 
18  votes will be diluted by the votes of persons who cast two or more votes or who fail to meet 
19  voter eligibility standards (ECF No. 2 at pp. 5-6).  According to Plaintiffs, this will likely 
20  occur  because  the  all-mail  primary  circumvents  various  legal  safeguards  designed  to 
21  protect the integrity of elections.  They suggest that the absence of safeguards is akin to 
22  โballot-box stuffingโ or altering ballots (ECF No. 2 at p. 7). Plaintiffs allege causes of 
23  action for:  
24  Count IโVote Dilution (ECF No. 1 at p. 8);  
25  Count IIโViolation of the Right to Vote for Legislative Representatives (ECF No. 1 
26  at p. 9); Count IIIโViolation of the Right to Vote under the Purcell Principle (ECF 
27  No. 1 at p. 10);    
28 
-2- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 3 of 15
 
1  Count IVโViolation of the Right to Vote in the Manner Chosen by the Nevada 
2  Legislature (ECF No. 1 at p. 11); and  
3  Count VโViolation of the Right to a Republican Form of Government (ECF No. 1 
4  at p. 12). 
5  Certain of the above causes of action are not cognizable under federal law (Counts 
6  II, III  and  V), while  others are  based  upon the  false premise  that  Nevadaโs all-mail 
7  primary election strips Nevada law of election integrity safeguards provided by state law 
8  (Counts I, IV, and V).  Additionally, because the alleged injury of vote dilution is based 
9  upon conjecture and speculation (Counts I-V), Plaintiffs have not demonstrated that they 
10  have  standing  to  challenge  Nevadaโs  all-mail  election.  Finally,  insofar  as  they  have 
11  manufactured abstract disputes concerning the manner of conducting elections (Count 
  12  IV), and the required structure of elections (Count V), Plaintiffs do not have standing to 
13  seek declaratory or equitable relief under Articles I and IV of the U.S. Constitution.1.      
14  III.  STANDARD OF REVIEW 
15  To obtain a preliminary injunction, Plaintiffs must demonstrate that (1) they are 
16  likely to succeed on the merits, (2) they are likely to suffer irreparable harm in the 
17  absence of preliminary relief, (3) the balance of equities tips in their favor, and (4) an 
18  injunction is in the public interest. Winter v. Natural Res. Def. Council, Inc., 555 U.S. 7, 
19  20, 129 S. Ct. 365, 172 L.Ed.2d 249 (2008).  This traditional test applies absent Plaintiffsโ 
20  ability to demonstrate that the balance of equities tips sharply in their favor.  Fox Broad. 
21  Co. v. Dish Network L.L.C., 747 F.3d 1060, 1066 n.2 (9th Cir. 2014).  Plaintiffs cannot 
22  meet this burden because they are unlikely to succeed on the merits, having generally 
23  non-cognizable claims.  Further, Plaintiffs will not suffer any harm, much less irreparable 
24  harm, unless one of their preferred candidates loses his or her primary race as a result of 
                                                 
25 
1  Plaintiffs have framed their arguments in a way to suggest that they have no 
intention of demonstrating their standing to bring claims for alleged violations of Articles 
26 
I and IV of the U.S. Constitution.  Federal law is clear that they do indeed have an 
27  obligation to prove standing in the form of a concrete injury (even when they allege 
violations  of  bedrock  principles  of  constitutional  governance).  See  Arizona  State 
28 
Legislature v. Arizona Independent Redistricting Commission, __U.S.__, 135 S.Ct. 2652, 
2663-65 (2015).   
-3- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 4 of 15
 
1  election fraud.  At this point, any harm to Plaintiffs is entirely speculative. Finally, the 
2  balance  of  equities  and  the  public  interest  during  these  unprecedented  times  weigh 
3  heavily against injunctive relief.   
4  The motion must be denied.     
5  IV.  ARGUMENT 
 
6  A.  Plaintiffs are Unlikely to Succeed on the Merits for Multiple Reasons 
 
7  1.  Secretary  Cegavske  is  Entitled  to  Judgment  on  the  Merits 
Because Plaintiffs Misrepresent Applicable Nevada Law  
8   
9  The Secretary of State is the Chief Officer of Elections for the state of Nevada.  
10  NRS  293.124.    As  such,  Secretary  Cegavske  may  approve  โmailing  precinctsโ  at  the 
11  request  of  Nevadaโs  county  election  officials.  NRS  293.213(4).  When  state  and  local 
  12  elections officials work together in this manner in pursuit of shared objectives, such as a 
13  common desire to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the population ceilings 
14  and other criteria set forth at subsections 1, 2 and 3 of NRS 293.213 are inapplicable. In 
15  other words, according to the plain language of subsection 4, a local election official โmay 
16  establish a mailing precinct โฆ that does not [exceed the stated population ceilings] if the 
17  county clerk obtains prior approval from the Secretary of State.โ   
18  As a practical matter, this means that state and local election officials may agree to 
19  establish  mailing  precincts  without  regard  to  the  number  of  voters  in  each  of  those 
20  precincts.  The manifest intent of subsection 4 is to address unforeseen circumstances 
21  compromising votersโ ability to access physical polling locations within any given region of 
22  the state. The COVID-19 pandemic has made such access deeply problematic throughout 
23  the entire state.  Consequently, Secretary Cegavskeโs decision to approve a statewide all-
24  mail primary not only satisfies the plain language of subsection 4, but is wholly consistent 
25  with its intent.  โWhen the Legislature's intent is clear from the plain language, this court 
26  will give effect to such intention and construe the statute's language to effectuate rather 
27  than nullify its manifest purpose.โ  We the People Nevada ex rel. Angle v. Miller, 124 Nev. 
28  874, 192 P.3d 1166, 1171 (2008).  Since all of Plaintiffsโ claims are premised, in one way or 
-4- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 5 of 15
 
1  another, upon alleged violations of state law, Secretary Cegavske is entitled to judgment 
2  in her favor on the merits.  
3  To  avoid  an  unfavorable  judgment  against  them,  Plaintiffs  conflate  โmailing 
4  precinctsโ and โabsent ballotsโ in an effort to cast doubt upon the legal validity of the 
5  scheduled all-mail primary (ECF No. 2 at 5-6, 12-13). By definition, an โabsent ballotโ is 
6  โa ballot voted by a person who expects to be or is absent from the polling place for his or 
7  her precinct or district on election day.โ NRS 293.013.  Although a voter need not offer an 
8  excuse for voting absentee, the voter must affirmatively request an absent ballot in order 
9  to cast the ballot by mail. NRS 293.313.  A mailing precinct, by contrast, is a precinct in 
10  which the registered voters are automatically mailed their ballots at their addresses of 
11  record. NRS 293.345.   
  12  As  Plaintiffs  observe,  the  submission  of  an  absent  ballot  is  governed  by  rules 
13  designed to ensure that a person who casts an absent ballot meets the voter eligibility 
14  criteria stated at Article 2, ยง 1 of the Nevada Constitution, including age and residency 
15  qualifications (ECF No. 2 at pp. 5-6, 12-13).  Accordingly, a person who requests an 
16  absent ballot is subject to the verification process that Plaintiffs describe in their motion 
17  for  injunctive  relief  (ECF  No.  2  at  pp.  5-6.).    Plaintiffs  agree  that  these  verification 
18  processes are designed to reconcile discrepancies between the voterโs address of record 
19  and a new address associated with the voterโs affirmative request for an absent ballot 
20  (ECF No. 2 at 6). Predictably, Plaintiffs fail to acknowledge that there is no need to 
21  reconcile such discrepancies with respect to mailing precincts. This is because there can 
22  be no discrepancies unless the voter affirmatively request an absent ballot in lieu of the 
23  standard ballot that will be mailed, unsolicited, to the voterโs address of record within the 
24  mailing precinct. 
25  In other words, if a voter plans to move to a new address before the standard ballot 
26  issues in the mail, the voter may request that an absent ballot be mailed to the voterโs 
27  new address.  Under these circumstances, if there is a discrepancy between the voterโs 
28  address of record and the new address associated with the voterโs affirmative request for 
-5- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 6 of 15
 
1  an absent ballot, the voter will be subject to the address reconciliation concerns that 
2  Plaintiffs have expressed in their motion for injunctive relief (ECF No. 2 at pp. 5-6.)  
3  There is no factual or legal basis for Plaintiffs to claim that voters will have the option to 
4  circumvent applicable election integrity measures.          
5  Likewise, there is no basis for Plaintiffs to claim that first-time voters will be able 
6  to  circumvent  the  identity  and  residency  verification  processes  that  are  periodically 
7  conducted at physical polling locations (ECF No. 2 at p. 12).  Plaintiffs incorrectly assert 
8  that first-time voters will be able to circumvent the requirements of NRS 293.2725(1) if 
9  they receive their ballots in the mail. As explained in the Declaration of Wayne Thorley 
10  (ECF No. 22 at p. 2), this is untrue because NRS 293.2725(2) sets forth an exception for 
11  first-time voters who submit to automated identity and residency verification as part of 
  12  the initial registration process, or who mail proof of identity and residency along with 
13  their ballots.  In summary, first-time voters must submit to the very same verification 
14  processes that apply to all elections, regardless of whether voting is conducted by mail or 
15  in person.      
16  As  a  final  matter,  Plaintiffs  falsely  claim  that  state  and  local  election  officials 
17  violated NRS 293.205 and .206 for failure to meet the deadline for changing precinct 
18  boundaries (ECF No. 2 at p. 6).  Since there were no changes to precinct boundaries, this 
19  argument is nonsensical.  The only change was to the method of voting within existing 
20  precinct boundaries. In light of the COVID-19 pandemic, voters residing within existing 
21  precinct boundaries will have the option to mail their ballots to the clerk or registrar of 
22  the county where they reside, thus obviating the need for those same voters to appear in 
23  person at physical polling locations within those precinct boundaries.2  With respect to 
24  voters such   as Plaintiffs who prefer to vote in person on election day, they may cast their 
                                                 
25 
2   Early  voting  procedures  have  rendered  precinct  boundaries  largely 
irrelevant in Nevada. During the 2-week period for early voting, voters may cast their 
26 
votes at any location where a vote center has been established. See NRS 293.356-.361. 
27  Effective January 1, 2020, the same is true on election day. See NRS 293.3072-.3075. 
Accordingly, there is little incentive for incumbent politicians to advocate for last-minute 
28 
changes to precinct boundaries in the hope that certain voters will be unable to locate 
their precincts on election day.  
-6- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 7 of 15
 
1  votes  at  a  countywide  vote  center  regardless  of  any  precinct  to  which  they  may  be 
2  assigned (ECF No. 22 at p. 4). See NRS 293.3072-.3075.  
 
3  2.  Plaintiffsโ Argument for Discarding the Anderson-Burdick Test  
is Unpersuasive 
4   
5    In  their  motion  for  injunctive  relief,  Plaintiffs  discuss  the  Anderson-Burdick 
6  balancing test at length, but ultimately urge the Court to discard it (ECF No. 2 at pp 8-9), 
7  replacing it with principles discussed in Bush v. Gore, 531 U.S. 98 (2000) (per curiam), 
8  and Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533 (1964).3  Those cases involved illegible ballots and a 
9  convoluted legislative apportionment scheme, respectively. Id.  Plaintiffs claim that the 
10  Anderson-Burdick balancing test is inapplicable because it is not useful for evaluating 
11  vote dilution claims (ECF No. 2 at 9).  As discussed below, however, Plaintiffsโ cause of 
  12  action for vote dilution is premised entirely upon speculation and conjecture.  While it is a 
13  colorful  analogy,  this  case  does  not  allege  facts  that  are  tantamount  to  โballot-box 
14  stuffingโ, nor does it implicate altered or destroyed ballots (ECF No. 2 at 7). 
15   Notwithstanding the hyperbole, Plaintiffsโ motion for injunctive relief ultimately 
16  expresses a disagreement with the policy of replacing in-person voting with mail-in voting 
17  for the 2020 primary election.  Since that policy is based upon Secretary Cegavskeโs 
18  reasonable interpretation of NRS 293.213(4), the only question for this Court is whether 
19  the  policy  unduly  burdens  Plaintiffsโ  voting  rights  relative  to  the  Stateโs  interest  in 
20  protecting  the  health  and  safety  of  its voters.    The  Anderson-Burdick  balancing  test 
21  provides the appropriate standard for evaluating Plaintiffsโ claims.  
22    According  to  the  Anderson-Burdick  line of cases,  โ[w]hen a  state  election law 
23  provision imposes only โreasonable, nondiscriminatory restrictionsโ upon the First and  
24  Fourteenth Amendment rights of voters, โthe State's important regulatory interests are 
25  generally sufficient to justifyโ the restrictions.โ Burdick v. Takushi, 504 U.S. 428, 434 
26  (1992) (quoting Anderson v. Celebrezze, 460 U.S. 780, 788 (1983)); see also Arizona Green 
27                                                   
3    Plaintiffsโ  reliance on  Bush v.  Gore  is misplaced,  given that  the  per  curiam 
28 
decision was limited to the circumstances in that case, involving the 2000 presidential 
election.  Id. at 109.   
-7- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 8 of 15
 
1  Party v. Reagan, 838 F.3d 983, 988 (9th Cir. 2016).  Here, Plaintiffs cannot demonstrate a 
2  burden upon their voting rights, only an imposition upon their preference for in-person 
3  voting.  By contrast, the Stateโs interest in protecting the health and safety of its voters is 
4  compelling.  Particularly during a global pandemic.  When applied to the allegations in 
5  this  case,  the  Anderson-Burdick  balancing  test  weighs  heavily  in  favor  Secretary 
6  Cegavske.  
7  3.  Plaintiffs Lack Standing for Their Speculative, Novel Claims 
8  Article III, ยง 2 of the U.S. Constitution states that the federal courts may only 
9  adjudicate โCasesโ and โControversiesโ. See Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 
10  559 (1992). The case-or-controversy requirement of Article III requires that Plaintiffs 
11  establish their โstandingโ as a jurisdictional prerequisite to the prosecution of this law 
  12  suit.  Clapper v. Amnesty International USA, 586 U.S. 398, 408 (2013).  To establish 
13  standing,  Plaintiffs  must  show  that  their  alleged  injury  is  โactual  or  imminent,  not 
14  conjectural or hypothetical.โ  Lujan, 504 U.S. at 560 (internal quotations and citations 
15  omitted).   Additionally, they must show a โcausal connectionโ between the alleged injury 
16  and the conduct about which they complain.  Id.   As a final matter, Plaintiffs may not 
17  offer mere speculation that a decision in their favor, namely a decision to require in-
18  person voting at physical polling locations throughout Washoe County, will redress their 
19  alleged injury. Id. at 561.   
20  Moreover, Plaintiffs must demonstrate standing separately for each form of relief 
21  sought.  Friends of the Earth, Inc. v. Laidlaw Envtl. Servs. (TOC), Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 185 
22  (2000).  Plaintiffs seek injunctive and declaratory relief with respect to each of their five 
23  causes of action.  However, their claim for vote dilution (Count I) is the only claim that 
24  even hints at the nature of their alleged injury. To establish standing, Plaintiffs must 
25  show that they have suffered an injury in fact that is fairly traceable to the challenged 
26  conduct of the defendants and is likely to be redressed by a favorable judicial decision. 
27  Lujan, 504 U.S. at   560โ61 (1992). Injury in fact is โthe โ[f]irst and foremostโ of standing's 
28  three  elements.โ  Spokeo  Inc.  v.  Robins,  136  S.  Ct.  1540,  1547  (2016)  (alteration  in 
-8- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 9 of 15
 
1  original) (quoting Steel Co. v. Citizens for a Better Env't, 523 U.S. 83, 103, 118 S.Ct. 1003, 
2  140 L.Ed.2d 210 (1998)). Among other things, โan injury in fact must be both concrete and 
3  particularized.โ Id. at 1548. 
4  Here, Plaintiffs allege a possible future injury in the form of vote dilution, but no 
5  injuries beyond that.  The specter of vote dilution โmay suffice if the threatened injury is 
6  certainly impending, or there is a substantial risk that the harm will occur.โ Susan B. 
7  Anthony List v. Driehaus, 573 U.S. 149, 158, 134 S. Ct. 2334, 189 L.Ed.2d 246 (2014) 
8  (internal  quotation  marks  omitted).    However,  Plaintiffs  must  still  prove  a  causal 
9  connection between the alleged injury and the alleged unlawful conduct on the part of 
10  Secretary Cegavske. Lujan, 504 U.S. at 560. 
11   As discussed above, Secretary Cegavske adhered to the letter of the law when she 
  12  worked in partnership with county election officials to implement an all-mail primary 
13  election for 2020.  Accordingly, there can be no causal connection between Plaintiffsโ 
14  alleged injury of vote dilution and the alleged violations of state law.  Plaintiffsโ claim to 
15  standing fails on this ground alone because there were no violations of state law.  For this 
16  reason, Secretary Cegavske is entitled to judgment in her favor on the merits, in addition 
17  to dismissal on jurisdictional grounds. 
18  Insofar as Plaintiffs imply that all-mail elections are inherently more vulnerable to 
19  election fraud than are in-person elections (ECF No. 2 at p. 12), their position is based 
20  entirely upon conjecture and speculation.  Five states, including Utah, have adopted all-
21  mail election processes on a permanent basis (ECF No. 22 at p. 3).  Their decision to adopt 
22  vote-by-mail elections indicates that they have great confidence in the integrity of mail-in 
23  processes.  Furthermore, Nevadaโs limited experience with mailing precincts has yielded 
24  no evidence of election fraud (ECF No. 22 at p. 3).  Not surprisingly, Plaintiffs have 
25  framed their case as a legal dispute rather than a factual dispute (ECF No. 4, pp. 1-4) 
26  because they have no evidence that their votes will be diluted by election fraud. 
27  In  short,  Plaintiffs  engage  in  unsupported  speculation  that  their  votes  in  the 
28  primary election will be diluted by election fraud resulting from a mish-mash of alleged 
-9- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 10 of 15
 
1  statutory  and  constitutional  violations.  Since  there  has  been  no  violation  of  state  or 
2  federal law, much less a showing that an alleged violation would cause vote dilution even 
3  if  it  had  occurred,  Plaintiffs  allegations  do  not  satisfy  Article  III  requirements  for 
4  standing.        
 
5  4.  There  is  Not  an  Unqualified  Right  under  Federal  Law  to 
Compel Adherence to State Voting Laws 
6   
7  As to Count II of their complaint, Plaintiffs argue that alleged ultra vires conduct 
8  by Secretary Cegavske, a member of the executive branch of Nevada state government, 
9  violates  their  right  to  vote  for  members  of  the  legislative  branch  of  Nevada  state 
10  government (ECF No. 2 at pp. 15-16.) Yet, Plaintiffs offer no explanation of how the 
11  administrative action of an executive branch official can, in and of itself, burden the 
  12  Plaintiffsโ right to freely cast a vote for their preferred choice of legislative candidates. To 
13  allege that an administrative action usurps a legislative power does not alone suffice to 
14  state a claim for a voting rights violation.  Here, the only connection to voting rights is the 
15  subject matter of the statutes that were allegedly violated. As discussed above, those 
16  statutes were not actually violated, but even if they had been violated, there would be no 
17  causal nexus between the violations and the alleged burden upon the right to vote for 
18  state legislators.   
19  Plaintiffs suggest, in summary, that the right to vote for a legislative candidate 
20  encompasses a right to protect that candidate, if elected, from future incursions upon his 
21  or her exercise of legislative powers.  This is an absurd proposition, and in substance, it 
22  merely raises a garden-variety separation of powers issue governed by state law, not a 
23  violation of voting rights guaranteed by the First and the Fourteenth Amendments to the 
24  U.S. Constitution. Because they cannot explain how the all-mail election burdens their 
25  right to vote for state legislators, only that it infringes upon state legislative powers, the 
26  Plaintiffsโ remedy for such an alleged violation is to file a writ petition in state court.  See 
27  NRS Chapter 34.   Indeed, if every clash between separate branches of state government 
28  could give rise to a cause of action for a voting rights violation, the federal courts would 
-10- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 11 of 15
 
1  become mired in endless litigation concerning the interpretation of state statutes and 
2  regulations.    
 
3  5.  The  โPurcell  Principleโ  and  Article  IV,  ยง  4  of  the  U.S. 
Constitution Confer no Private Causes of Action 
4   
5  Plaintiffs acknowledge that federal case law does not, at present, support their 
6  claim for an alleged violation of Article IV, ยง 4 of the U.S. Constitution, given that the 
7  claim presents a non-justiciable political question (ECF No. 2 at p. 19). See Luther v. 
8  Borden,  48  U.S.  1  (1849).    They  argue,  however,  that  the  U.S.  Supreme  Court  โhas 
9  severely  cut  back  on  [the]  political-question  doctrineโ  (ECF  No.  2  at  p.  19),  thus 
10  suggesting that the Supreme Court may abandon the abstention doctrine altogether once 
11  it reviews the facts in this case.  Since that is highly improbable, this Court should reject 
  12  the claim. 
13  With regard to Purcell v. Gonzalez, 541 U.S. 1 (2006), the U.S. Supreme Court 
14  vacated a pre-election injunction because the Ninth Circuit had issued the injunction on 
15  the eve of the election. Id. at 5-6.  In this context, the holding of Purcell can only be 
16  construed as an admonition to the federal courts, not as the foundation for a private cause 
17  of  action.    It  is  generally  understood  that  that  federal  statutes  and  constitutional 
18  provisions are the source of rights enforceable in the federal district courts.  See Gonzaga 
19  University v. Doe, 536 UI.S. 273, 283 (2002) (โWe now reject the notion that our cases 
20  permit anything short of an unambiguously conferred right to support a cause of action 
21  brought under ยง 1983โ).  The Purcell case neither states nor implies that its holding was 
22  intending to confer enforceable rights upon private plaintiffs.  Moreover, it undermines 
23  Plaintiffsโ  request  for  injunctive  relief  here  because  it  is  Plaintiffs  who  seek  court 
24  alterations to election processes at the proverbial 11th hour.  If anything Purcell advises 
25  against the issuance of an injunction by this Court. 
26  โฆ 
27   
28   
 
-11- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 12 of 15
 
B.  Plaintiffs Cannot Demonstrate Irreparable Harm, as Adequate 
1  Remedies Exist to Address Their Speculative Claims after  
the Primary Election 
2   
3  Like other equitable remedies, injunctions require a showing that irreparable harm 
4  is probable and not speculative. Nevada v. United States, 364 F.Supp.3d 1146, 1154 (D. 
5  Nev. 2019).  At this preliminary stage of the electoral process, Plaintiffsโ alleged injuries 
6  are speculative, rendering them incapable of being remedied by way of injunctive relief. 
7  See Siegel v. LePore, 120 F.Supp.2d 1041, 1052-53 (S.D. Fla. 2000) (โ[W]e find Plaintiffs' 
8  alleged injuries on an as-applied basis to be speculative, and far from irreparable, at this 
9  stage in the electoral recount process.โ)  Here, even assuming Plaintiffs correctly predict 
10  some harm (they do not), they make no effort to articulate why the appropriate remedy 
11  for that harm should not be fashioned after the primary election, when the source and the 
  12  nature of the harm might conceivably be ascertained. See Curry v. Baker, 802 F.2d 1302, 
13  1314 (11th Cir.1986) (โAlthough federal courts closely scrutinize state laws whose very 
14  design infringes on the rights of voters, federal courts will not intervene to supervise the 
15  administrative  details  of  a  local  election.  Only  in  extraordinary  circumstances  will  a 
16  challenge to a state election rise to the level of a constitutional deprivation.โ) (internal 
17  citation omitted).   
18  C.  The Balancing of Equities Favors Defendant Cegavske 
19  Plaintiffsโ  analysis  does  not  state  the  full  standard  for  balancing  equities.    โA 
20  preliminary injunction is an extraordinary remedy never awarded as of right.  In each 
21  case, courts โmust balance the competing claims of injury and must consider the effect on 
22  each party of the granting or withholding of the requested relief.โ  Winter, 555 U.S. at 24 
23  (internal citations omitted).   
24  Instead,  Plaintiffs  presume,  based  on  their  (refuted)  statutory  analysis  that 
25  Defendants have no cognizable interest in the plan for an all-mail primary election.  This 
26  is simply not true, ignoring the global pandemic, as  recognized by the World Health 
27  Organization, the United States, and Nevada.  Defendant Cegavske, as Nevadaโs chief 
28  election  officer,  has  an  obligation  to  conduct  the  primary  election  in  a  manner  that 
-12- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 13 of 15
 
1  protects Nevadaโs citizens by allowing them to exercise their right to vote securely while 
2  not being  denied this right by being forced to make a Hobsonโs choice between their 
3  franchise and their health.  Granting injunctive relief now will force Nevadaโs citizens to 
4  do so.   
5  Further, in an ironic twist, granting injunctive relief at the late hour violates the 
6  โPurcell principleโ Plaintiffs mistakenly contend is a cognizable claim here.  Having the 
7  judiciary  alter  election  procedures  within  the  statutory  discretion  of  state  and  local 
8  officials at the proverbial โ11th hourโ would create confusion during this public health 
9  emergency.   
10  Accordingly,  the  equities  balance  in  favor  of  Defendants  in  this  case,  further 
11  warranting denial of the motion.   
  12  D.  The Public Interest Strongly Favors Defendant Cegavske 
13  Plaintiffsโ  analysis  does  not  state  the  full  standard  for  considering  the  public 
14  interest.  โIn exercising their sound discretion, courts of equity should pay particular 
15  regard for the public consequences in employing the extraordinary remedy of injunction.โ  
16  Winter,  555  U.S.  at  24.    Similar  to  Winterโs  consideration  of  military  interests, 
17  Nevada is currently in battle with the most significant public health emergency in over a 
18  century.  To be clear, after the World Health Organization declared a pandemic, President 
19  Trump  declared  a  nationwide  emergency  on  March  13,  2020.    See   
20  https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/proclamation-declaring-national-
21  emergency-concerning-novel-coronavirus-disease-covid-19-outbreak/.    Governor  Sisolak 
22  declared a Nevada emergency on March 12, 2020 (ECF No. 2 at p. 21).  Both the state and 
23  federal emergencies remain in effect.   
24  Further, there is no genuine doubt that Nevada has the power to protect the health 
25  of its citizens, particularly in an emergency such as this.  Prior to ratification of the 
26  Constitution,  various  colonies  had  quarantine  laws,  thereby  establishing  the  legal 
27  tradition of local and state jurisdiction over matters of public health reflected in the 
28 
-13- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 28   Filed 04/27/20   Page 14 of 15
 
1  Constitutionโs reservation of power to the states to regulate public health, safety, and 
2  morals.  Gibbons v. Ogden, 22 U.S. 1 (1824). 
3  It is in this context that Plaintiffs seek to substitute their judgment of the public 
4  interest for those representing us in the local, state, and federal government (ECF No. 2 
5  at  pp.  21-22).  Plaintiffsโ  contention  that  the  preliminary  injunction  favors  the  public 
6  interest in contrast to the global pandemic respectfully does not pass the laugh test.   
7  Recognizing  the  unprecedented  global  pandemic,  state  and  local  officials  came 
8  together to work within existing statutory authority to ensure a fair Nevada primary 
9  election while minimizing health risks to its voters.  As set forth above, Plaintiffs only 
10  have speculation to support their claim that voting rights are being violated under these 
11  circumstances.  Granting the preliminary injunction would simply create further chaos 
  12  during an emergency.  This prong strongly warrants denial of the motion.   
13  V.  CONCLUSION 
14    At most, this case presents a policy dispute about the relative merits of in-
15  person  voting  processes  and  vote-by-mail  processes  during  a  pandemic.  Secretary 
16  Cegavske acted within her authority, pursuant to NRS 293.213(4), to approve an all-mail 
17  election for the 2020 primary election.  Her actions, and those of local election officials, 
18  have  not  imposed  a  discernable  burden  upon  Plaintiffsโ  voting  rights,  nor  have  they 
19  created an increased risk of election fraud.  For these reasons, the Court should deny 
20  Plaintiffsโ motion for declaratory and injunctive relief. 
21  DATED this 27th day of April 2020.  
AARON D. FORD

21  through her attorney of record, Christopher J. Hicks, Washoe County District Attorney, and 
22  Herbert B. Kaplan, Washoe County Deputy District Attorney, and hereby move to dismiss the

24  This Motion is brought pursuant to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and is based on 
25  the following Memorandum of Points and Authorities, and all the pleadings and papers on file 
26  herein. 
 
-1- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 62   Filed 05/11/20   Page 2 of 5
 
1  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
2  I.  ANALYSIS AND DISCUSSION  
3    A.  Procedural Background   
4  Plaintiffs filed a Complaint (ECF #1) asserting that the all-mail primary election 
5  scheduled for June 9, 2020, is invalid.   Plaintiffs simultaneously filed a motion for preliminary 
6  injunction (ECF #2) in an attempt to prevent the Nevada Secretary of State and the Washoe 
7  County Registrar of Voters from conducting the June 9, 2020, Nevada state and federal primary 
8  election from proceeding under the โall-mail electionโ plan.  
9    In the Complaint, Plaintiffs pray for the following relief: 
10    1.  Declare that the Plan violates the right to vote the First and Fourteenth 
Amendments of the U.S. Constitution and Nev. Const. art 2, ยง 1. Article 1, ยงยง 8 and 9 of 
11  the Nevada Constitution and strips safeguards against fraudulent votes that dilute legal 
votes;  
12  2. Declare that the Plan violates the right to vote under the First and Fourteenth 
Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, as well as Article 2, ยง 1 of the Nevada 
13  Constitution, because the Secretary and County Administratorsโ Plan overrules and 
replaces the legislatorโs chosen manner of elections;  
14  3. Declare that the Plan violates the right to vote under the Purcell Principle;  
4. Declare that the Plan violates Article I, ยง 4 , cl. 1 of the U.S. Constitution;  
15  5. Declare that the Plan violates the Votersโ right to a republican form of 
government under Article IV, ยง 4 of the U.S. Constitution;  
16  6. Preliminarily and permanently enjoin the Secretary and County Administrators 
from conducting the Plan in violation of the Votersโ right to vote;  
17  7. Preliminarily and permanently enjoin the Secretary and County Administrators 
to implement the primary election in the manner the Nevada Legislature prescribed. 
18   
 
19  Complaint at pp. 12-13.  
20  Plaintiffs also filed a motion to consolidate hearing on motion for preliminary injunction

8  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) mandates that a court dismiss a cause of action 
9  that fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.  A motion to dismiss under FRCP 
10  12(b)(6) tests the complaintโs sufficiency.  N. Star Intโl v. Ariz. Corp. Commโn, 720 F.2d 578 
11  (9th Cir. 1983).  When considering a motion to dismiss, dismissal is appropriate only when the 
12  complaint does not give the defendant fair notice of a legally cognizable claim and the grounds 
13  on which it rests.  Bell Atl. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 555 (2007).  A formulaic recitation of a 
14  cause of action with conclusory allegations is not sufficient, a plaintiff must plead facts showing 
15  that a violation is plausible, not just possible.  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 566 U.S. 662 (2009)(citations 
16  omitted). In considering whether the complaint is sufficient to state a claim, the court will take 
17  all material allegations as true and construe them in the light most favorable to the plaintiff.  NL 
18  Indus. Inc. v. Kaplan, 792 F.2d 896, 898 (9th Cir. 1986).  The court, however, is not required to 
19  accept as true allegations that are merely conclusory, unwarranted deductions of fact, or 
20  unreasonable inferences.  Sprewell v. Golden State Warriors, 266 F.3d 979, 988 (9th Cir. 2001).

In the Ninth Circuit, the sliding-scale preliminary-injunction test is as follows:
24
Plaintiffs seeking a preliminary injunction must establish that: (1) they are likely to succeed

relief; (3) the balance of equities tips in their favor; and (4) an injunction is in the public

nary injunction may still issue so long as โthe balance of hardships tips sharply in the

1 plaintiff's favorโ and the other two factors are satisfied. Shell Offshore, Inc. v. Greenpeace,
Inc., 709 F.3d 1281, 1291 (9th Cir. 2013) (quoting Alliance for the Wild Rockies v. Cottrell,
2 632 F.3d 1127, 1135 (9th Cir. 2011)).
3 Short v. Brown, 893 F.3d 671, 675 (9th Cir. 2018) (emphasis in original)
4 On the merits-success prong, โthe burdens at the preliminary injunction stage track the bur-

6 (2006); see also id. at 428 (citing Ashcroft v. ACLU, 542 U.S. 656, 666 (2004); FEC v. Wiscon-
7 sin Right to Life,, 551 U.S. 449, 464 (2007); United States v. Playboy Entmโt Group, Inc., 529
8 U.S. 803, 816 (2000). So for example, where provisions burden free-speech rights, the burden is
9 on the government to justify its provision under strict scrutiny. Finally, in First Amendment

22

23
ternal citations omitted). โAnd the right of suffrage can be denied by a debasement or dilution of
24
the weight of a citizenโs vote just as effectively as by  wholly prohibiting the free exercise of the
25
franchise.โ Id. The right to vote inheres in, and is protected by, the First and Fourteenth Amend-
26
ments of the U.S. Constitution.
27
28

3 the electors at such election.โ Nev. Const. art 2, ยง 1. Article 1, ยงยง 8 and 9 of the Nevada Consti-

6 Sadler, 58 P. 284, 288 (1899) (โThe right to vote . . . could not be given stronger or broader lan-
7 guage.โ); Buckner v. Lynip, 41 P. 762, 764 (1895) (โright of voting, and, of course, of having the
8 vote counted is one of most transcendent importanceโthe highest under our form of govern-
9 ment.โ) And under Nevadaโs right to vote, restrictions on these rights are strictly scrutinized with
10 restrictions causing disenfranchisement struck. See id. (โThat one entitled to vote shall not be
11 deprived of his privilege by action of the authorities is a fundamental principle.โ). Nevada courts
12 โlook to federal precedent for guidanceโ on due-process protections. Hernandez v. Bennet-
13 Haron, 287 P.3d 305, 310 (2012).
14 The level of scrutiny to be applied to the Plan under the federal right to vote would be strict
15 scrutiny if the Anderson-Burdick test applies because mandatory safeguards against vote fraud
16 have been stripped, which dilutes votes and thus is a severe burden. That test requires โweighing

20 the plaintiffโs rights.โโ Burdick v. Takushi, 504 U.S. 428, 434 (1992) (quoting Anderson v.
21 Celebrezze, 460 U.S. 780, 788โ89 (1983)). Under this test, strict scrutiny applies to โburdensโ
22 deemed โsevereโ (at issue here) as follows, id. at 434:
23 the rigorousness of our inquiry into the propriety of a state election law depends upon the
extent to which a challenged regulation burdens First and Fourteenth Amendment rights.
24 Thus, as we have recognized when those rights are subjected to โsevereโ restrictions, the
regulation must be โnarrowly drawn to advance a state interest of compelling importance.โ
25 Norman v. Reed, 502 U.S. 279, 289 (1992). But when a state election law provision im-
poses only โreasonable, nondiscriminatory restrictionsโ upon the First and Fourteenth
26 Amendment rights of voters, โthe Stateโs important regulatory interests are generally
sufficient to justifyโ the restrictions. Anderson, 460 U.S. at 788; see also id., at 788-789,
27 n. 9.

12 (citing Reynolds, 377 U.S. at 582).
13 In Kerr v. Hickenlooper, 744 F.3d 1156 (10th Cir. 2014), the Tenth Circuit decided that
14 political-question doctrine didnโt prevent considering a Guarantee Clause claim against a voter-
15 initiative constitutional amendment, though that was vacated and remanded by Kerr, 135 S. St. 2927
16 (2015), and ultimately resolved on lack of ordinary Article III standing, 824 F.3d 1207, 1217 (10th
17 Cir. 2016). Other courts have considered Guarantee Clause claims on the merits. See, e.g., Largess
18 v. Supreme Judicial Court; Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians v. Superior Court, 148 P.3d
19 1126, 1137-39 (Cal. 2006); Vansickle v. Shanahan, 511 P.2d 223, 234 (Kan. 1973).
20 Scholars advocate and foresee Guarantee Clause challenges being allowed by the Supreme
21 Court. See, e.g., Erwin Chemerinsky, Cases Under the Guarantee Clause Should Be Justiciable, 65
22 U. Colo. L. Rev. 849, 864-69 (1994); see also id. at 851 (โ[T]he time is clearly approaching in which
23 the Court may . . . reject the view that cases under the Guarantee Clause should always be dismissed
24 on political question grounds.โ); Laurence H. Tribe, American Constitutional Law 398 (2d ed. 1988):
25 John Hart Ely, Democracy and Distrust: a Theory of Judicial Review 118 n.* (1980).
26 The Plan presents a case where a Guarantee Clause challenge should not be deemed a political
27 question. In Clinton, the U.S. Supreme Court limited political questions to where there is either a
28 clear โconstitutional commitmentโ to some political branch or โa lack of judicially discoverable and
19

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 2   Filed 04/21/20   Page 20 of 22
1 manageable standards.โ 566 U.S. at 195. Only the โstandardsโ issue might apply here. While such
2 โstandardsโ might be difficult in some situations, they are not here. The Plan substitutes the Secretary
3 and County Administrators for the Legislature in doing the exclusively legislative function of
4 establishing the โmannerโ of this election. The U.S. Supreme Court would simply need to hold that
5 in a republican form of government, state and local officials may not usurp the legislative role and
6 the rule of law and so declare the Plan unconstitutional under the Guarantee Clause and enjoin it. So
7 the Plan violates the Guarantee Clause and the similar protection of the Nevada Constitution.
8 *    *    *
9 In sum, Voters have a strong likelihood of success on all their claims, so that the other
10 preliminary-injunction elements readily follow, particularly since the right to vote is based on the
11 First and Fourteenth Amendments. And even were any particular claim deemed to present only
12 โserious questions going to the merits,โ the preliminary injunction is proper because โโthe balance
13 of hardships tips sharply in [Votersโ] favorโ and the other two factors are satisfied.โ Short, 893 F.3d
14 at 675 (citation omitted).
15 B. Voters have irreparable harm.
16 Voters have irreparable harm for reasons tracking their claims. They have no remedy at law if
17 the Plan proceeds and the election is held in violation of Votersโ constitutional rights. If the Plan
18 proceeds, their right to vote, to have equal protection, and to a federal election compliant with the
19 federal constitution under Articles I, ยง 4, cl. 1 and IV, ยง 4 will be violated. See supra Part II.A. In
20 Obama for America, 888 F. Supp. 2d 897 (S.D. Oh. 2012), affโd, 697 F.3d 423, the district court
21 readily found irreparable harm after finding likely merits success on the right-to-vote claim, id. at
22 910. That should happen here because constitutional violations caused by the Plan canโt be repaired
23 after the election.
24 C. The balance harms favors the injunction.
25 The balance of harms favors the injunctionโsharply, were that required for any claim. 
26 On Votersโ side are core, fundamental, constitutional rights that are violated by the Plan if it is
27 allowed to proceed. That typically suffices in constitutional challenges, or else rights arenโt rights.
28
20

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 2   Filed 04/21/20   Page 21 of 22
1 On the Secretary of Stateโs and County Administratorโs side is a Plan that is not authorized by
2 the Legislature, is in violation of controlling laws, and seems to have been done without considering
3 fundamental constitutional and rule-of-law mandates that govern their work. Defendants can have
4 no cognizable interest in advancing the Plan if, as shown, it is highly likely that the Plan violates
5 constitutional and statutory provisions.
6 D. The public interest favors the injunction.
7 The public interest favors following the rule of law by obeying constitutional and statutory
8 mandates and protecting constitutional rights. The public interest favors having elections held under
9 controlling authorities. 
10 Now, it is true that Defendants recite the Plan as being responsive to the health risks from the
11 COVID-19 pandemic, to which Voters are of course sympathetic. And naturally the public has an
12 interest in health and safety, and the Governor has issued an  Emergency Declaration concerning
13 coronavirus.  See https://d1q4hslcl8rmbx.cloudfront.net/assets/uploads/2020/03/Declaration-of-
14 Emergency-re-COVID.pdf; see alsohttp://gov.nv.gov/News/Emergency_Orders/Emergency_Orders/
15 (Governorโs emergency orders). But that doesnโt mean Defendants can jettison constitutional and
16 statutory rights and  mandates and fashion a remedy essentially out of whole cloth. Defendantsโ only
17 options are to do what the controlling constitutional and statutory provisions permitโotherwise the
18 rule of law fails. Within that rule of law, is where they must find their remedy.
19 And Defendants do have permissible options that they should be doing instead of their forbidden
20 Plan. Early and regular voting can be held in compliance with recommendations to practice social
21 distancing, hand sanitizing, and wearing personal protection equipment, just as people do at the
22 grocery store and other essential places and functions. To the extent, the Governor were to have the
23 authority to bar in-person voting by classifying it as nonessential and were to do so  (on which Voters
24 donโt opine except to note that it would not be consistent with U.S. Constitution Article I, ยง 4, cl.
25 1 for a federal election), then the normal absentee-ballot process must control. Actual absentee
26 ballots may be requested and cast under normal procedures and anti-fraud safeguards. Instead of
27 advising the public that mail-in ballots will be automatically mailed to all active, registered voters,
28 Defendants should be using their same time and communication channels to tell all registered voters
21

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 2   Filed 04/21/20   Page 22 of 22
1 to quickly request an actual absentee ballot and return it as the law requires. That will leave in place
2 the normal safeguards for actual absentee ballots that are lost with the Plan.
3 So the public interest favors following the rule of law and abiding by constitutional and statutory
4 mandates. It favors the requested preliminary injunction.
5 Conclusion
6 For the reasons show, this Court should preliminarily enjoin the Plan.
7
Respectfully submitted,
8
/s/ David OโMara
