1 BARBARA CEGAVSKE, in her official 
capacity as Nevada Secretary of State, 
2 DEANNA SPIKULA, in her official capacity 
as Registrar of Voters for Washoe County, and 
3 JOSEPH P. GLORIA, in his official capacity as 
Registrar of Voters for Clark County, 
4  
Defendants, 
5  
and 
6
NEVADA STATE DEMOCRATIC PARTY, 
7 DNC SERVICES 
CORPORATION/DEMOCRATIC 
8 NATIONAL COMMITTEE, DCCC, 
PRIORITIES USA, and JOHN SOLOMON, 
9
Intervenor-
10 Defendants. 
 
11  
  Intervenor-Defendants here, by and through their attorneys of record, move to dismiss 
12
Plaintiffsโ Amended Verified Complaint. This motion is based upon the Memorandum of Points 
13
& Authorities below, all pleadings, paper, and exhibits on file in this matter, and any oral 
14
argument the Court sees fit to allow. 
15
INTRODUCTION 
16
  Plaintiffs, individual Nevada voters represented by the organization True the Vote, have 
17
filed this lawsuit in an effort to prevent Defendants from acting to protect the Nevada electorate 
18
in the face of the coronavirus pandemic. The relief they now seek in their unreasonably delayed 
19
amended complaint would cause a massive and wasteful disruption of Nevadaโs plans for the 
20
June 9, 2020 primary election. Because their causes of actions are factually unsupported and 
21
legally unsound, this Court should dismiss their amended complaint with prejudice. 
22
  This Court has already held, in ruling on Plaintiffsโ initial motion for a preliminary 
23
injunction, that Plaintiffs lack standing because their primary claimed injuryโthe dilution of 
24
their votes based on the specter of increased illegal voting if Nevada changes from an absent 
25
ballot  voting  system  to  an  automatic  vote  by  mail  systemโis  entirely  speculative  and  a 
26
generalized grievance. Plaintiffsโ amended complaint does nothing to remedy this fundamental 
27
flaw, and instead serves only to compound the original complaintโs shortcomings by introducing 
28
2 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 3 of 16
 
1 new, untenable causes of action coupled with further distortions of the law and the facts. 
2 BACKGROUND 
3   On March 24, 2020, Defendant Barbara Cegavske, the Nevada Secretary of State (the 
4 โSecretaryโ)โalong with Defendant Deanna Spikula, the Registrar of Voters for Washoe County 
5 (the โWashoe Registrarโ), Defendant Joseph P. Gloria, the Registrar of Voters for Clark County 
6 (the โClark Registrarโ), and election officials from Nevadaโs 14 other counties and Carson 
7 Cityโannounced a plan to conduct the June 9, 2020 primary election (the โJune Primaryโ) 
8 predominantly by mail, to protect voters and elections officials in the face of the growing health 
9 crisis. See Amended Verified Complaint (โAm. Compl.โ), ECF No. 64, ยถ 20. In the weeks that 
10 followed, county officials began posting notices describing their specific plans to adapt voting in 
11 light of the pandemic. Id. ยถยถ 26โ37. An essential feature of the plan for the June Primary is the 
12 mailing of ballots to registered voters, without the need for voter requests. Id. ยถ 21. 
13   On April 21, 2020, Plaintiffs filed this lawsuit, contending that Nevada election officials 
14 do not have authority under Nevada law to proactively mail ballots to voters. See Verified 
15 Complaint (โCompl.โ), ECF No. 1. That same day, Plaintiffs followed with a motion for a 
16 preliminary injunction. See ECF No. 2. On April 27, Intervenor-Defendants filed a motion to 
17 intervene, which this Court granted. See ECF Nos. 27, 39. 
18   Following  a  hearing,  the  Court  issued  an  order  denying  Plaintiffsโ  motion  for  a 
19 preliminary injunction on April 30, 2020. See Order, ECF No. 57. The Court concluded that 
20 โPlaintiffs have not established an injury particularized to them to confer standing,โ and that 
21 even if they had standing, their โclaims fail on the merits.โ Id. at 2. 
22   Subsequently, on May 4, the Clark Registrar announced a revised election plan for the 
23 June Primary in a court document filed in Intervenor-Defendantsโ state court action. Am. Compl. 
24 ยถ 39.1 Among these revisions were the decisions to provide two additional in-person voting 
25                                                  
26
1   As discussed at greater length in their motion to intervene, see ECF No. 27 at 3โ4 & n. 2, 
four of the Intervenor-Defendants, along with a group of Nevada voters, filed an action in 
27
Nevada state court against Defendants on April 16, 2020. Id. at 3 & Ex. 3; see also Corona v. 
Cegavske, No. 20-OC-00064-1B (Nev. Dist. Ct. Apr. 16, 2020). Crucially, and contrary to 
28
(footnote continued) 
3 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 4 of 16
 
1 locations and mail ballots to all registered voters, active and inactive alike. Id. The Clark 
2 Registrar also plans to appoint field registrars to collect sealed ballots from voters. Id. ยถ 40. 
3   Plaintiffs filed their amended complaint on May 13, 2020. In addition to dropping two of 
4 their original causes of action,2 Plaintiffs include Count I, a recast of their original Count II, 
5 which generally alleges a violation of the Nevada Legislatureโs electoral policies, compare 
6 Compl. ยถยถ 45โ49, with Am. Compl. ยถยถ 97โ102โbut now with the added allegation that voters 
7 will be directly disenfranchised, Am. Compl. ยถ 105. And Plaintiffs add a new cause of action, 
8 Count IV, which claims that the Clark Registrarโs revised plans for Clark County voters violate 
9 the Equal Protection Clause of the U.S. Constitution. See id. ยถยถ 123โ28. These causes of action 
10 join two claims imported from Plaintiffsโ original complaintโCount II, a right to vote claim 
11 premised on purported vote dilution, see id. ยถยถ 108โ16, and Count III, which alleges a violation 
12 of the U.S. Constitutionโs Elections Clause, see id. ยถยถ 117โ22. 
13 LEGAL STANDARD 
14   A  plaintiff  bears  the  burden  of  establishing  federal  subject  matter  jurisdiction  by  a 
15 preponderance of the evidence. United States ex rel. Solis v. Millennium Pharms., Inc., 885 F.3d 
16 623, 625 (9th Cir. 2018). Where, as here, a โfacialโ challenge is brought under Federal Rule of 
17 Civil Procedure 12(b)(1), the moving parties โassert[] that the allegations contained in [the] 
18 complaint are insufficient on their face to invoke federal jurisdiction,โ but โdo not โdispute[] the 
19 truth of the allegations.โโ Lacano Invs., LLC v. Balash, 765 F.3d 1068, 1071 (9th Cir. 2014) 
20 (alterations in original) (quoting Safe Air for Everyone v. Meyer, 373 F.3d 1035, 1039 (9th Cir. 
21 2004)). Moreover, a plaintiff must demonstrate Article III standing for each form of relief 
22 sought. Friends of Earth, Inc. v. Laidlaw Envtl. Servs. (TOC), Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 185 (2000). 
23                                                  
24 Plaintiffs in this case, Intervenor-Defendants โdo not object to Defendantsโ expansion of vote by 
mail; indeed, the current public health crisis necessitates that states allow voters to cast ballots 
25 without leaving their homes.โ ECF No. 27 at 3โ4. 
26 2   Plaintiffsโ amended complaint no longer includes the original complaintโs Count III, a 
claim premised on the U.S. Supreme Courtโs decision in Purcell v. Gonzalez, 549 U.S. 1 (2006) 
27 (per  curiam),  see  Compl.  ยถยถ 50โ55,  or  Count  V,  which  alleged  a  violation  of  the  U.S. 
Constitutionโs Guarantee Clause, see id. ยถยถ 62โ66. 
28
4 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 5 of 16
 
1 โ[T]he irreducible constitutional minimum of standing contains three elements.โ Lujan v. Defs. 
2 of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560 (1992). โThe plaintiff must have (1) suffered an injury in fact, 
3 (2) that is fairly traceable to the challenged conduct of the defendant, and (3) that is likely to be 
4 redressed by a favorable judicial decision.โ Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins, 136 S. Ct. 1540, 1547 (2016). 
5   To survive a motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6), a complaint must โstate a claim to 
6 relief that is plausible on its face.โ Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009) (quoting Bell Atl. 
7 Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 570 (2007)). Although a court must โtake all of the factual 
8 allegations in the complaint as true,โ id. (citing Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555), โ[f]actual allegations 
9 must be enough to raise a right to relief above the speculative level.โ Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555. 
10 โRule 12(b)(6) permits dismissal on the basis of either (1) the โlack of a cognizable legal theory,โ 
11 or (2) โthe absence of sufficient facts alleged under a cognizable legal theory.โโ Newlands Asset 
12 Holding Tr. v. SFR Invs. Pool 1, LLC, No. 3:17-cv-00370-LRH-WGC, 2017 WL 5559956, at *2 
13 (D. Nev. Nov. 17, 2017) (quoting Balistreri v. Pacifica Police Depโt, 901 F.2d 696, 699 (9th Cir. 
14 1990)). 
15 ARGUMENT 
16   This Court should grant Intervenor-Defendantsโ motion to dismiss because as to each 
17 claim, Plaintiffs lack standing, fail to state a claim upon which relief can be granted, or both.3 
18
I.  Count I should be dismissed for lack of standing and for failure to state a claim 
upon which relief can be granted. 
19
20   Count  I  of  Plaintiffsโ  amended  complaint  alleges,  like  their  original  claims,  that 
21 Defendantsโ decision to proactively mail ballots to voters violates Nevada law. See Am. Compl. 
                                                 
22
23 3   Intervenor-Defendants  recognize  that  this  Court  might  not  entertain  an  Eleventh 
Amendment immunity defense unless Defendants themselves raise it. But because the Court can 
24 raise the issue sua sponte, see United States ex rel. Burlbaw v. Orenduff, 548 F.3d 931, 942 (10th 
Cir.  2008)  (citing  Wis.  Depโt  of  Corr.  v.  Schacht,  524  U.S.  381,  389  (1998)),  Intervenor-
25 Defendants note that โ[t]he Eleventh Amendment prevents a federal court  from  issuing  an 
injunction against state officials solely to require them to adhere to state law.โ Thompson v. 
26 Alabama, No. 2:16-CV-783-WKW, 2017 WL 3223915, at *8 (M.D. Ala. July 28, 2017); see also 
Pennhurst State Sch. & Hosp. v. Halderman, 465 U.S. 89, 106โ07 (1984); Neuwirth v. La. State 
27 Bd. of Dentistry, 845 F.2d 553, 557 (5th Cir. 1988). That is precisely the sort of relief that 
Plaintiffs seek from this Court. See Am. Compl. at 25โ26. 
28
5 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 6 of 16
 
1 ยถยถ 97โ102. Appended to this old assertion is the novel claim that the mailing of ballots will lead 
2 to disenfranchisement. See id. ยถ 105. Plaintiffs, however, never connect these two contentions. 
3 And they certainly provide no allegations that give rise to a plausible claim that Defendantsโ 
4 decision to proactively mail ballots to voters will lead to disenfranchisement or any other injury. 
5 All Plaintiffs are left with, then, is their previous assertion that they have a right to seek 
6 enforcement of their incorrect reading of Nevada lawโa claim that this Court has already 
7 rejected. See Order at 14โ20. Accordingly, Count I fails on both standing and Rule 12(b)(6) 
8 grounds. 
9 A.  Plaintiffs lack standing to assert Count I. 
10   To be sure, disenfranchisement, or the serious risk thereof, is an injury-in-fact cognizable 
11 under  Article  III.  But  alleging  a  cognizable  injury  without  connecting  that  injury  to  the 
12 challenged  conduct  fails  to  establish  standing.  Instead,  โthere  must  be  a  causal  connection 
13 between the injury and the conduct complained ofโthe injury has to be โfairly . . . trace[able] to 
14 the challenged action of the defendant, and not . . . th[e] result [of] the independent action of 
15 some third party not before the court.โ Lujan, 504 U.S. at 560โ61 (alterations in original) 
16 (quoting Simon v. E. Ky. Welfare Rights Org., 426 U.S. 26, 41โ42 (1976)).  
17   Plaintiffs  have  not  connected  the  conduct  they  challengeโDefendantsโ  decision  to 
18 proactively mail ballots to voters in purported violation of Nevada lawโwith the injury they 
19 assertโdisenfranchisement. Cf. Order at 10 n. 7 (โEven if the Court had concluded [] that there 
20 was a violation of Nevada law in the implementation of the all-mail provisions of the Plan, . . . 
21 Plaintiffs have not established a nexus between such alleged violations and the alleged injury of 
22 vote  dilution.โ).  As  an  initial  matter,  Plaintiffs  have  not  articulated  why  the  decision  to 
23 proactively mail ballots to voters is more likely to result in disenfranchisement simply because it 
24 isโallegedlyโagainst the law. Instead, they merely take this conclusion for granted, despite the 
25 absence of a plausible, logical explanation. See Am. Compl. ยถ 107 (โDue to this widespread 
26 disenfranchisement caused by not abiding by the legislatureโs law, the Plans violates the right to 
27 vote by direct disenfranchisement.โ). Nor have Plaintiffs otherwise explained how exactly the 
28 proactive  mailing  of  ballots,  whether  countenanced  by  state  law  or  not,  will  result  in 
6 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 7 of 16
 
1 disenfranchisementโparticularly  in  comparison  to  their  preferred  method  of  voting,  absent 
2 ballots.  Indeed,  Defendantsโ  decision  to  mail  ballots  to  voters  without  first  requiring  the 
3 submission and processing of absent ballot applications will almost certainly result in more 
4 voting, not less. See Order at 14 (โ[I]f the Plan is not implemented voters worried about risks to 
5 their health or unsure about how to obtain an absentee ballot may very well be discouraged from 
6 exercising the right to vote all together.โ); cf. Am. Compl. ยถยถ 85, 89โ90 (describing Wisconsinโs 
7 inability to process the surge in absentee ballot requests caused by the pandemic). 
8   Accordingly, Plaintiffsโ amended complaint, like their initial complaint, falls well short 
9 of establishing the necessary traceability and redressability needed to establish standing for 
10 Count  I.  Because  they  have  failed  to  establish  standing  for  this  claim,  Count  I  should  be 
11 dismissed. 
12
B.  Count I fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted because the 
U.S. Constitution is not a vehicle to enforce state election laws. 
13
14   Plaintiffsโ failure to connect Defendantsโ purported violation of state law with any injury 
15 to or interference with their ability to vote also dooms Count I under Rule 12(b)(6). See Iqbal, 
16 556 U.S. at 678 (โRule 8 . . . demands more than an unadorned, the-defendant-unlawfully-
17 harmed-me accusation.โ). Without alleging any nexus between the challenged policy and an 
18 alleged burden on the right to vote, Count Iโlike its predecessor, Count II in Plaintiffsโ initial 
19 complaint, see Compl. ยถยถ 45โ49โcontinues to do nothing more than assert the right to have 
20 Plaintiffsโ incorrect reading of Nevada law enforced. But โ[t]he Constitution is not an election 
21 fraud statute.โ Minn. Voters All. v. Ritchie, 720 F.3d 1029, 1031 (8th Cir. 2013) (quoting Bodine 
22 v. Elkhart Cty. Election Bd., 788 F.2d 1270, 1271 (7th Cir. 1986)) (affirming Rule 12(b)(6) 
23 dismissal of vote dilution claim). And the allegations in the amended complaint do not give rise 
24 to a plausible claim that Defendantsโ decision to mail ballots to Nevada votersโthe only policy 
25 at issue in this case, see Order at 1 n. 1โprevents Plaintiffs from casting ballots or otherwise 
26 burdens their right to vote. 
27   Plaintiffsโ efforts to enforce Nevada law through Count I (as well as Count II) ignore that 
28 federal  voting  rights  cases  permit  plaintiffs  to  bring  suit  in  federal  court  under  two 
7 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 8 of 16
 
1 circumstances: (1) where the defendantsโ actions violate a federal statute, see, e.g., Sanchez v. 
2 Cegavske, 214 F. Supp. 3d 961, 965โ66 (D. Nev. 2016), or (2) where the defendants are applying 
3 state elections law in a manner that violates the federal constitution, see, e.g., PEST Comm. v. 
4 Miller, 648 F. Supp. 2d 1202, 1214โ15 (D. Nev. 2009). There is no precedent for a federal court 
5 to grant relief under the U.S. Constitution to voters who simply contend, as Plaintiffs here do, 
6 that state election officials are acting in contravention of state law. In four filingsโthe initial 
7 complaint, the first motion for a preliminary injunction, the amended complaint, and the second 
8 motion for a preliminary injunctionโPlaintiffs have not identified a single case that allows them 
9 to seek this relief. Because the U.S. Constitution does not provide the right that Plaintiffs seek to 
10 vindicate in Count I, it fails to state a claim under a cognizable legal theory, and dismissal of that 
11 claim is therefore appropriate. See Parents for Privacy v. Barr, 949 F.3d 1210, 1226 (9th Cir. 
12 2020) (affirming dismissal with prejudice where claim was โpremised on the violation of an 
13 asserted right that, as a matter of law, is not protected byโ the U.S. Constitution). 
14
C.  Count I fails as a matter of law because it rests on an incorrect interpretation 
of Nevadaโs election laws. 
15
16   Lastly, Count Iโlike all of Plaintiffsโ claims premised on alleged violations of Nevada 
17 lawโfails as a matter of law because, as this Court has already held, Defendantsโ decision to 
18 mail ballots to registered voters in Nevada is explicitly countenanced by Nevada statute. See 
19 Order at 16โ20. Through the laws governing mailing precinctsโspecifically, Nevada Revised 
20 Statutes (โN.R.S.โ) 293.343 through 293.355โthe Nevada Legislature has given the Secretary 
21 and the county clerks authority to mail ballots to all registered voters, rather than requiring voters 
22 to request those ballots through the absent ballot process. The documents attached to Plaintiffsโ 
23 amended complaint confirm that Defendants have followed these procedures. Compare Am. 
24 Compl., Exs. CโH, with N.R.S. 293.213(4)โ(5). Plaintiffsโ claim instead hinges on a labored 
25 reading of different statutes, N.R.S. 293.205 and 293.206, which, as this Court has already held, 
26 govern only the physical boundaries of precincts and not the manner of elections conducted 
27 therein. See Order at 17โ18; see also N.R.S. 293.205(2) (โThe boundaries of each election 
28 precinct must follow visible ground features.โ); N.R.S. 293.205(3) (โElection precincts must be 
8 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 9 of 16
 
1 composed only of contiguous territory.โ); N.R.S. 293.206(1) (governing submission of maps 
2 โshowing the boundariesโ of election precincts). Even if N.R.S. 293.205 were applicable to the 
3 manner of conducting elections within a precinct, it explicitly imports another statute, N.R.S. 
4 293.208, which allows a new precinct to be created โat any time if it lies entirely within the 
5 boundaries of any existing precinct.โ N.R.S. 293.208(3). Because each existing precinct has been 
6 converted to a mailing precinct for the June Primary without any further change, the now-
7 designated mailing precincts share overlapping boundaries with, and therefore lie entirely within, 
8 the existing precincts.  
9   As this Court has previously concluded, Count I (like Counts II and III) rests on an 
10 interpretation of state law that is wrong as a matter of law. Because it fails to state a claim upon 
11 which relief can be granted for this and other reasons, and because Plaintiffs lack standing to 
12 assert it, Count I must be dismissed. See Iqbal, 556 at 678; Ditech Fin. LLC v. Res. Grp. LLC, 
13 398 F. Supp. 3d 801, 803 (D. Nev. 2019) (granting motion to dismiss where plaintiffโs legal 
14 theory โfail[ed] as a matter of lawโ), appeal docketed, No. 19-16427 (9th Cir. July 19, 2019). 
15
II.  Count II should be dismissed for lack of standing and for failure to state a claim 
upon which relief can be granted. 
16
17   Count IIโwhich alleges that a predominantly vote by mail election will dilute the value 
18 of  Plaintiffsโ  votes  in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments,  see Am. Compl. 
19 ยถยถ 108โ16โis virtually identical to Count I of Plaintiffsโ original complaint. Compare id., with 
20 Compl. ยถยถ 36โ44. This Court has already correctly rejected this claim on both standing grounds 
21 and the merits. See Order at 8โ9, 11โ14. The allegations in the amended complaint have not 
22 remedied this claimโs fundamental flaws, and dismissal is therefore warranted. 
23 A.  Plaintiffs lack standing to bring Count II. 
24   Plaintiffs, new and old alike, continue to assert an interest in having Nevadaโs election 
25 laws enforced based on their statuses as registered voters, and suggest that Defendantsโ purported 
26 failure to enforce Nevadaโs laws in the manner Plaintiffs see fit could lead to an increase in 
27 illegal votes harmful to lawful voters. But as this Court has already held, that interest represents 
28 no more than a generalized grievance that is insufficient for Article III purposes. See Order at 9 
9 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 10 of 16
 
1 (โPlaintiffsโ purported injury of having their votes diluted due to ostensible election fraud may be 
2 conceivably raised by any Nevada voter. Such claimed injury therefore does not satisfy the 
3 requirement that Plaintiffs must state a concrete and particularized injury.โ); see also Lujan, 504 
4 U.S. at 573โ76 (โ[A]n injury amounting only to the alleged violation of a right to have the 
5 Government act in accordance with law [is] not judicially cognizableโ and โcannot alone satisfy 
6 the requirements of Art. III without draining those requirements of meaning.โ (quoting Allen v. 
7 Wright, 468 U.S. 737, 754 (1984))); cf. United States v. Florida, No. 4:12cv285-RH/CAS, 2012 
8 WL 13034013, at *1 (N.D. Fla. Nov. 6, 2012) (rejecting True the Voteโs motion to intervene 
9 under Rule 24 based on the same theory of vote dilution because its โasserted interests are the 
10 same . . . as for every other registered voter in the stateโ). Moreover, Plaintiffsโ purported injury 
11 is wholly conjectural, see Order at 9, and such speculative injuries do not confer Article III 
12 standing. See Am. Civil Rights Union v. Martinez-Rivera, 166 F. Supp. 3d 779, 789 (W.D. Tex. 
13 2015) (โ[T]he risk of vote dilution[ is] speculative and, as such, [is] more akin to a generalized 
14 grievance about the government than an injury in fact.โ). 
15   In short, as the Court previously concluded, Plaintiffs do not have standing to bring this 
16 claim. Count II should therefore be dismissed. 
17
B.  Count II fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted because vote 
dilution by illegal voting is not a viable legal theory. 
18
19   Count II fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted because it is not premised 
20 on  a  cognizable  legal  theory.  See  Newlands  Asset  Holding  Tr.,  2017  WL  5559956,  at  *2 
21 (dismissal appropriate where claim lacks โa cognizable legal theoryโ (quoting Balistreri, 901 
22 F.2d at 699)). To begin, Count II, like its predecessor, continues to ask this Court to enforce the 
23 Nevada Legislatureโs election policies. See Am. Compl. ยถยถ 113, 116; see also id. at 25โ26. But 
24 the U.S. Constitution is not a vehicle to enforce state election laws. See Part I.B supra. And even 
25 if it were, Defendantsโ plans are consistent with state law. See Part I.C supra; Order at 16โ20. 
26   Moreover, federal courts do not recognize a cause of action under the theory that illegal 
27 voting will cause vote dilution as asserted in Count II. While it is true that vote dilution is a 
28 viable basis for federal claims in certain contexts, such as when laws are crafted that structurally 
10 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 11 of 16
 
1 devalue one communityโs votes over anotherโs, see, e.g., Republican Party of Pa. v. Cortรฉs, 218 
2 F. Supp. 3d 396, 406โ07 (E.D. Pa. 2016); see also Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 568 (1964) 
3 (โSimply stated, an individualโs right to vote for state legislators is unconstitutionally impaired 
4 when its weight is in a substantial fashion diluted when compared with votes of citizens living on 
5 other parts of the State.โ), in these cases, plaintiffs allege that their votes are devalued as 
6 compared to similarly situated voters in other parts of the state. See Reynolds, 377 U.S. at 567โ
7 68. Plaintiffs here, by contrast, have not alleged that Defendantsโ plan to mail ballots values 
8 some other group of votes over their own. Nor does their complaint give rise to the plausible 
9 claim that they belong to a group of voters that will be disparately impacted by a supposed surge 
10 in illegal voting. Accordingly, they have failed at the most basic step of pleading an equal 
11 protection claim.  
12   Nor have Plaintiffs cited any authority for taking vote dilution out of the equal protection 
13 context and transforming it into a weapon that voters may use to enlist the federal judiciary to 
14 make it more difficult for their fellow citizens to vote. Cf. Short v. Brown, 893 F.3d 671, 677โ78 
15 (9th Cir. 2018) (โNor have the appellants cited any authority explaining how a law that makes it 
16 easier to vote would violate the Constitution.โ). To the contrary, courts have routinelyโand 
17 appropriatelyโrejected such efforts. See Minn. Voters All., 720 F.3d at 1031โ32 (affirming Rule 
18 12(b)(6)  dismissal  of  vote  dilution  claim);  see  also  Cortรฉs,  218  F.  Supp.  3d  406,  406โ07 
19 (rejecting claim of vote dilution by illegal voting on motion for preliminary injunction). Because 
20 Plaintiffs have failed to allege facts that give rise to a plausible claim for relief, or even alleged a 
21 cognizable legal theory, dismissal of Count II is appropriate.   
22
III.  Count III should be dismissed for lack of standing and for failure to state a claim 
upon which relief can be granted. 
23
24   Count III, which is identical to a claim in Plaintiffsโ original complaint that this Court has 
25 already  rejected,  see  Order  at  20,  invokes  the  U.S.  Constitutionโs  Elections  Clause,  which 
26 provides  that  โ[t]he  Times,  Places  and  Manner  of  holding  Elections  for  Senators  and 
27 Representatives, shall be prescribed in each State by the Legislature thereof.โ U.S. Const., art. I, 
28 ยง 4, cl. 1; see also Am. Compl. ยถยถ 117โ22. But significantlyโand fatallyโPlaintiffs do not and 
11 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 12 of 16
 
1 cannot produce any authority establishing a private right of action under this clause. Cf. U.S. 
2 House of Representatives v. Burwell, 130 F. Supp. 3d 53, 78 (D.D.C. 2015) (noting private 
3 citizens generally lack power to โdeputiz[e] themselves in an effort to enforce federal lawโ). 
4 Indeed, courts have rejected similar efforts to assert private rights to enforce structuralโas 
5 opposed to rights-focusedโconstitutional provisions. See, e.g., Largess v. Supreme Judicial 
6 Court, 373 F.3d 219, 228 & n. 9 (1st Cir. 2004) (per curiam) (affirming denial of injunctive relief 
7 where โindividuals . . . attempt[ed] to invoke the Guarantee Clause against state officialsโ).  
8   Count III also suffers the same flaws as Count II. Plaintiffsโ asserted injury for both is the 
9 sameโan alleged violation of Nevada laws that will lead to an increase in illegal votingโand as 
10 this Court has already held, that injury is neither concrete and particularized nor actual or 
11 imminent. See Order at 8โ9. Similarly, Count III shares the flawed, central contention of Counts 
12 I and II that Defendants are violating Nevada law by mailing ballots to voters. See Part I.C supra. 
13   Because Plaintiffs do not have standing to assert Count III, the Elections Clause does not 
14 create a private right of action to enforce state law, and the claim rests on an incorrect reading of 
15 Nevada statute, Count III should be dismissed. 
16
IV.  Count IV should be dismissed for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be 
granted. 
17
18   Finally, Count IV challenges two of Clark Countyโs recently announced revisions to its 
19 plan for the June Primaryโnamely, the decisions to mail ballots to both active and inactive 
20 voters and to appoint field registrars to collect ballots from individuals for whom returning 
21 ballots by mail is difficult. See Am. Compl. ยถยถ 123โ28; see also id., Ex. P. Plaintiffs reason that 
22 Clark County voters will have an easier time voting, and will therefore vote in higher numbers 
23 than voters who live in counties that are not taking these steps. See id. ยถ 126. Intervenor-
24 Defendants agree that these recently announced revisions will expand access to the franchise for 
25 Clark County voters; that is why they have brought a lawsuit in state court to ensure these types 
26 of protections are in place in every Nevada county. Confoundingly, though, Plaintiffs do not ask 
27 this Court to order the Washoe Registrar and other county officials to similarly mail ballots to 
28 inactive voters and appoint field registrars to assist voters statewide. Instead, Plaintiffs seek an 
12 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 13 of 16
 
1 order from this Court preventing Clark County from helping its voters cast ballots by prohibiting 
2 these recently announced revisions. Id. at 25โ26. 
3   Plaintiffsโ attempt to reduce access to the ballot for Clark County voters is squarely 
4 foreclosed by the Ninth Circuitโs opinion in Short v. Brown. In Short, the plaintiffs alleged that 
5 Californiaโs  Voterโs  Choice  Act  (โVCAโ)  violated  the  Equal  Protection  Clause  because  it 
6 permitted voters in some counties to receive a mail ballot automatically, while voters in other 
7 counties had to apply for a mail ballot. 893 F.3d at 677โ79. The plaintiffs contended that the 
8 VCA  โinequitably  โdilutesโ  votes  in  โdisfavoredโ  counties.โ  Id.  at  677.  The  Ninth  Circuit 
9 affirmed the district courtโs denial of a preliminary injunction because the plaintiffs had โnot 
10 even allegedโlet alone introduced evidence to demonstrateโthat the VCA [would] prevent 
11 anyone from voting.โ Id. Significantly, in Short, the Ninth Circuit rejected the premise that the 
12 U.S. Constitution prohibits states from making it easier to vote, or that the vote dilution line of 
13 cases  applies  to  challenges,  like  this  one,  where  a  state  has  not  allocated  representation 
14 differently among voters. Id. at 677โ78. So too here. Plaintiffs have not alleged any facts that 
15 give rise to the plausible claim that Clark Countyโs plans to mail ballots to inactive voters and 
16 appoint field registrars will make it harder for anyone to vote, let alone themselves. And they 
17 have not, in any of their pleadings, cited authority for the proposition that the U.S. Constitution 
18 somehow prohibits election officialsโ earnest efforts to make it easier to vote. 
19   Bush v. Gore, 531 U.S. 98 (2000) (per curiam), does not save Plaintiffsโ claim. In the 
20 immediate  aftermath  of  the  disputed  2000  presidential  election,  the  U.S.  Supreme  Court 
21 concluded that the manual recount ordered by the Florida Supreme Court, which did not provide 
22 consistent  standards  and  โminimal  procedural  safeguards,โ  offended  the  Equal  Protection 
23 Clauseโs requirement of non-arbitrary treatment of voters. Id. at 108โ09. Here, by significant 
24 contrast, Plaintiffs have not alleged that their ballotsโor anyone elseโsโwill be arbitrarily 
25 rejected. 
26   Because Count IV is squarely foreclosed by controlling Ninth Circuit precedent, it fails to 
27 allege a claim upon which relief can be granted. Accordingly, dismissal is warranted. See Conant 
28 v. Brown, 248 F. Supp. 3d 1014, 1024โ25 (D. Or. 2017) (granting motion to dismiss where 
13 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 71   Filed 05/19/20   Page 14 of 16
 
1 plaintiffโs arguments were โforeclosed by . . . precedentโ); see also Newlands Asset Holding Tr., 
2 2017 WL 5559956, at *2.4 
3 V.  Dismissal should be with prejudice. 
4   โ[D]ismissal with prejudice is warranted [where] amendment would be futile.โ Carter v. 
5 Sables, LLC, No. 3:17-cv-00594-MMD-WGC, 2017 WL 6328157, at *2 (D. Nev. Dec. 11, 
6 2017); see also United States v. Gila Valley Irrigation Dist., 859 F.3d 789, 804 (9th Cir. 2017) 
7 (leave to amend should not be granted where โamendment would cause prejudice to the opposing 
8 party, is sought in bad faith, is futile, or creates undue delayโ (quoting Madeja v. Olympic 
9 Packers, LLC, 310 F.3d 628, 636 (9th Cir. 2002)). 
10   Here, any amendment Plaintiffs might pursue to salvage their claims would be futile. 
11 Plaintiffs lack standing to bring their speculative and generalized claimsโa fatal deficiency that, 
12 having amended once, they have not cured despite receiving this Courtโs previous ruling on the 
13 issue. There is no indication that Plaintiffs could conceivably add a plaintiff who would remedy 
14 this ongoing flaw. Moreover, Plaintiffsโ claims are based on incorrect interpretations of Nevada 
15 law, and rely on legal theories that are either improper or beyond the scope of the constitutional 
16 provisions on which they rely. For all these reasons, further amendment would be futile. See 
17 Parents for Privacy, 949 F.3d at 1226 (affirming dismissal of claim with prejudice where claim 
18 was โpremised on the violation of an asserted right that, as a matter of law, is not protectedโ by 
19 the U.S. Constitution). 
20   Finally, granting leave to amend would create prejudice and undue delay. Plaintiffs 
21 already  delayed  in  filing  their  amended  complaint  and  second  motion  for  a  preliminary 
22 injunction. Now, the June Primary is less than three weeks away. There is simply insufficient 
23 time  for  Plaintiffs  to  file,  and  this  Court  to  adjudicate,  a  second  amended  complaint. 
                                                 
24
25 4   Plaintiffs also suggest that Clark Countyโs plan violates Nevada election laws. See Am. 
Compl. ยถ 126. This is not so. N.R.S. 293.345(1) requires county election officials to mail a ballot 
26 to โeach registered voterโ in all mailing precinctsโin other words, active and inactive voters 
alike. And Nevada law explicitly allows county officials to โappoint at least one registered voter 
27 to serve as a field registrar of voters.โ N.R.S. 293.505(2). These field registrars are empowered 
to โperform such duties as the county clerk may direct,โ id., including the collection of ballots. 
28
14

1

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
3 
 
DISTRICT OF NEVADA 
4 
 
* * * 
5 
 
6  STANLEY WILLIAM PAHER, et al.,  Case No. 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC 
   
7  Plaintiffs,  ORDER 
  v. 
8   
 
9  BARBARA CEGAVSKE, in her official 
capacity as Nevada Secretary of State, et 
10  al., 
 
11  Defendants. 
 
12   
13  I.  SUMMARY 
14  Plaintiffs1  challenge  a  plan  (โthe  Planโ)  that  the  Nevada  Secretary  of  State 
15  (โSecretaryโ), in partnership with Nevadaโs 17 county election officials,2 developed to 
16  implement an all-mail election for the upcoming June 9, 2020, Nevada primary election to 
17  address public health concerns caused by the spread of the coronavirus disease (โCOVID-
18  19โ)  in  Nevada.  Proposed  Intervenors-Defendants  (โProposed  Intervenorsโ)3  seek 
19  intervention as  a matter  of  right under  Federal  Rule  of  Civil  Procedure  24(a)(2),  or 
20  alternatively, as permissive under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 24(b)4. (ECF No. 27.) 
21  The Court will grant the motion to intervene (โMotionโ).  
22 
 
23  1Plaintiffs are registered Nevada voters: William Paher, Gary Hamilton, Terresa 
Monroe-Hamilton. (ECF No. 1 at 3.) 
24   
  2Plaintiffs also name as a defendant the Registrar of Voters for Washoe County. 
25  (ECF No. 1.) 
 
26  3Proposed  Intervenors  are  Nevada  State  Democratic  Party,  DNC  Services 
Corporation/Democratic National Committee, DCCC, Priorities USA, and John Solomon. 
27  (ECF No. 27 at 1.) 
 
28    4The Court directed any response to the Motion to be filed by April 28, 2020, at 
12:00 pm PST. (ECF No. 34.) No response was filed within the prescribed time. 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 39   Filed 04/28/20   Page 2 of 6
 
1  II.  BACKGROUND 
2  The following facts are taken from the Verified Complaint and exhibits attached 
3  thereto. 
4  This action challenges the Secretaryโs decision to conduct an all-mail election for 
5  the June 9, 2020, primary. (ECF No. 1-1.) In the press released issued on March 24, 2020, 
6  the Secretary explained that the decision to implement the Plan was made to โmaintain a 
7  high level of access to the ballot, while protecting the safety of voters and poll workers[โ
8  who belong to groups who are at high risks for severe illness from COVID-19โ].โ (Id.)  
9  Under the Plan, all active registered voters will be mailed an absentee ballot (mail-
10  in ballot) for the primary election. If a voter is registered to vote at his or her current 
11  address, they need not take any further action to receive an absentee ballot. (E.g., ECF 
12  No. 1-3.) If an individual is not registered or needs to update registration information (e.g., 
13  such as name, address, and party), they are required to do so. (Id.) To accommodate 
14  same-day registration requirements enacted by the 2019 Nevada Legislature, the Plan 
15  also establishes at least one physical polling place in each of Nevadaโs counties and in 
16  Carson City. (ECF No. 1-1.)  
17  Perhaps  without  much  surprise  to  anyone  who  has  followed  states  efforts  to 
18  manage elections during this pandemic, the Plan faces legal challenges in both this Court 
19  and the state court. Here, Plaintiffs assert five claims for relief and request declaratory and 
20  injunctive relief to prevent the Secretary and county administrators from implementing the 
21  Plan. (ECF No. 1 at 8โ13.) They particularly challenge the Planโs expansion of mail-in 
22  voting or in their characterization, โ[t]he Plan would require the State to forego almost all 
23  in-person voting and instead conduct the Primary by mailed absent ballots.โ (ECF No. 1 
24  at  9.)  In  contrast,  in  a  lawsuit  filed  in  state  court  (โState  Court  Actionโ),  Proposed 
25  Intervenors โdo not object to Defendantsโ expansion of vote by mailโ but they assert where 
26  the Plan fall short is its failure to provide โmeaningful opportunities for in-person votingโ 
27  among other deficiencies. (ECF No. 27 at 3โ4 & n.2; ECF No. 27-3 at 3โ5.) And just as 
28  Proposed  Intervenors  have  moved  to  intervene  in  this  action,  the  group  supporting 
 
2 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 39   Filed 04/28/20   Page 3 of 6
 
1  Plaintiffs have moved to intervene in the State Court Action. (ECF No. 27-1 at 5 n.3 (stating 
2  that โTrue the Vote, representing two different individual voters, filed a motion to intervene 
3  in the State Court Action, raising exactly the same arguments they have raised in this 
4  caseโ).) 
5  III.  DISCUSSION 
6    The Court agrees with Proposed Intervenors that intervention is warranted as a 
7  matter of right under Rule 24(a) and as permissive under Rule 24(b). 
8    A.  Intervention under Rule 24(a) 
9    When evaluating motions to intervene as a matter of right, courts construe Rule 24 
10  liberally in favor of potential intervenors, focusing on practical considerations rather than 
11  technical distinctions. Sw. Ctr. for Biological Diversity v. Berg, 268 F.3d 810, 817 (9th Cir. 
12  2001). Nonetheless, an applicant for intervention bears the burden of showing that he/she 
13  is entitled to intervene. United States v. Alisal Water Corp., 370 F.3d 915, 919 (9th Cir. 
14  2004).  
15  Rule 24(a) permits anyone to intervene who โclaims an interest relating to the 
16  property or transaction that is the subject of the action, and is so situated that disposing 
17  of the action may as a practical matter impair or impede the movantโs ability to protect [his] 
18  interest,  unless  existing  parties  adequately  represent  that  interest.โ  Fed.  R.  Civ.  P. 
19  24(a)(2). A party seeking to intervene by right must meet four requirements: 
20  (1) the applicant must timely move to intervene; (2) the applicant 
must have a significantly protectable interest relating to the property 
21  or transaction that is the subject of the action; (3) the applicant must 
be situated such that the disposition of the action may impair or 
22  impede  the  partyโs  ability  to  protect  that  interest;  and  (4)  the 
applicantโs interest must not be adequately represented by existing 
23  parties. 
 
24  Freedom from Religion Found., Inc. v. Geithner, 644 F.3d 836, 841 (9th Cir. 2011) 
25  (citations  omitted).  โFailure  to  satisfy  any  one  of  the  requirements  is  fatal  to  the 
26  application.โ Id. (quoting Perry v. Prop. 8 Official Proponents, 587 F.3d 947, 950 (9th Cir. 
27  2009)). 
28  /// 
 
3 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 39   Filed 04/28/20   Page 4 of 6
 
1      1.  Factor One: Timeliness 
2  โTimeliness is โthe threshold requirementโ for intervention as of right.โ League of 
3  United Latin Am. Citizens v. Wilson, 131 F.3d 1297, 1302 (9th Cir.1997) (quoting United 
4  States v. Oregon, 913 F.2d 576, 588 (9th Cir.1990)). Proposed Intervenors moved for 
5  intervention within six days from the filing of the action and before the reply brief in support 
6  of Plaintiffsโ motion for preliminary injunction is due under the Courtโs expedited briefing 
7  schedule. (ECF Nos. 1, 27.) There is no question that their Motion is timely. 
8  2.  Factors  Two  and  Three:  Significant  Protectable  Interest  and 
  Impairment of That Interest 
9 
10  Generally โ[a]n applicant has a โsignificant protectable interestโ in an action if (1) 
11  [he] asserts an interest that is protected under some law, and (2) there is a โrelationshipโ 
12  between [his] legally protected interest and the plaintiffโs claims.โ Cal. ex rel. Lockyer v. 
13  United States, 450 F.3d 436, 441 (9th Cir. 2006) (quoting Donnelly v. Glickman, 159 F.3d 
14  405, 409 (9th Cir. 1998)). However, โ[t]he โinterestโ test is not a bright-line rule.โ Alisal, 370 
15  F.3d at 919 (citations omitted). 
16  Proposed Intervenors argue that Plaintiffsโ success on their claims would disrupt 
17  the organizational intervenorsโ efforts to promote the franchise and ensure the election of 
18  Democratic Party candidates, and individual intervenor John Solomonโs plan to vote by 
19  mail. (ECF No. 27 at 7.) Proposed Intervenors have sufficiently shown that they maintain 
20  significant protectable interests which would be impaired by Plaintiffsโ challenge to the 
21  Planโs  all-mail  election  provisions.  That  a  group  of  voters  similar  to  Plaintiffs  have 
22  apparently  moved  to  intervene  in  Proposed  Intervenorsโ  State  Court  Action  further 
23  underscores the significance of the interests at stake and that impairment of the ability to 
24  protect the various interests will likely result should intervention be disallowed here.  
25    3.  Factor Four: Adequacy of Representation 
26   Courts  consider  three  factors  when  assessing  whether  a  present  party  will 
27  adequately represent the interests of an applicant for intervention: 
28  /// 
 
4 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 39   Filed 04/28/20   Page 5 of 6
 
1  (1) whether the interest of a present party is such that it will undoubtedly 
make all of a proposed intervenorโs arguments; (2) whether the present 
2  party is capable and willing to make such arguments; and (3) whether a 
proposed intervenor would offer any necessary elements to the proceeding 
3  that other parties would neglect. 
 
4  Arakaki v. Cayetano, 324 F.3d 1078, 1086 (2003). Moreover, โ[t]he burden of showing 
5  inadequacy of representation is โminimalโ and satisfied if the applicant can demonstrate 
6  that representation of its interests โmay beโ inadequate.โ Citizens for Balanced Use v. 
7  Montana Wilderness Assโn, 647 F.3d 893, 898 (9th Cir. 2011) (quoting Arakaki, 324 F.3d 
8  at 1086). 
9  Proposed Intervenors insist that because they disagree that the other aspects of 
10  the Plan are adequate to extend the franchise for all Nevada voters, their interests do not 
11  fully align with that of Defendants and Defendants therefore cannot adequately protect 
12  their interests in this action. (ECF No. 27 at 8โ9.) However, in terms of this action, 
13  Proposed  Intervenorsโ  interests  do  not  appear  to  diverge  significantly  from  that  of 
14  Defendants. Both groups presumably share the goal of protecting the all-mail election 
15  provisions of the Plan being challenged here. Nevertheless, Proposed Intervenors do not 
16  agree that the Plan goes far enough to protect the franchise, as evidenced by their State 
17  Court Action, and may present arguments about the need to safeguard Nevadanโs right to 
18  vote that are distinct from Defendantsโ arguments. Indeed, a comparison of Defendantsโ 
19  response brief (ECF No. 28) and Proposed Intervenorsโ opposition brief (ECF No. 27-1) 
20  reveal divergent arguments.  
21  Having considered the relevant factors under Rule 24(a), the Court agrees with 
22  Proposed Intervenors that they have demonstrated entitlement to intervene as a matter of 
23  right. 
24  B.  Intervention under Rule 24(b) 
25  Even if intervention as of right was not warranted in this case, Proposed Intervenors 
26  have demonstrated that they meet the requirements of permissive intervention.  
27  Rule 24(b)(1)(B) permits a court to allow anyone to intervene who submits a timely 
28  motion and โhas a claim or defense that shares with the main action a common question 
 
5 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 39   Filed 04/28/20   Page 6 of 6
 
1  of law or fact.โ An applicant โwho seeks permissive intervention must prove that it meets 
2  three threshold requirements: (1) it shares a common question of law or fact with the main 
3  action; (2) its motion is timely; and (3) the court has an independent basis for jurisdiction.โ 
4  Donnelly, 159 F.3d at 412. Because a court has discretion in deciding whether to permit 
5  intervention, it should consider whether intervention will cause undue delay or prejudice 
6  to the original parties, whether the applicantโs interests are adequately represented by the 
7  existing parties, and whether judicial economy favors intervention. Venegas v. Skaggs, 
8  867 F.2d 527, 530โ31 (9th Cir. 1989).  
9  Proposed  Intervenors  have  shown  permissive  intervention  is  warranted.  Their 
10  motion is timely, they assert similar defenses in support of the Planโs all-mail election 
11  provisions, and their opposition brief raises arguments in response to Plaintiffsโ challenges 
12  to the Plan and does not assert issues unrelated to this action. (See discussion supra.) 
13  Moreover, the Court finds intervention will not cause delay or prejudice given that the 
14  Motion was filed before Plaintiffsโ reply brief was due and before the scheduled hearing 
15  on the merits.  
16  IV.  CONCLUSION 
17  The Court notes that the parties made several arguments and cited to several cases 
18  not discussed above. The Court has reviewed these arguments and cases and determines 
19  that they do not warrant discussion as they do not affect the outcome of the motion before 
20  the Court. 
21  It is therefore ordered that Proposed Intervenors-Defendantsโ motion to intervene 
22  (ECF No. 27) is granted.  
23  DATED THIS 28th day of April 2020. 
24   
25                           
            MIRANDA M. DU 
26               CHIEF UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE 
27 
28

9 Pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 24, Proposed Intervenor-Defendants Nevada 
10 State Democratic Party (โNSDPโ), DNC Services Corporation/Democratic National Committee 
11 (โDNCโ), DCCC, Priorities USA, and John Solomon (collectively, โProposed Intervenorsโ) 
12 move to intervene as defendants in the above-titled action.  
13 Plaintiffs  Stanley  William  Paher,  Terresa  Monroe-Hamilton,  and  Garry  Hamilton 
14 challenge the election plans instituted by Defendants Barbara Cegavske, the Nevada Secretary of 
15 State (the โSecretaryโ), and Deanna Spikula, the Registrar of Voters for Washoe County (the 
16 โWashoe  Registrarโ),  for  the  June  9,  2020  Nevada  primary  election  (the  โJune  Primaryโ). 
17 Defendantsโ decision to implement a nearly all-mail election for the June Primary is not just 
18 reasonable, but constitutionally required to ensure that Nevada voters can safely exercise their 
19 franchise in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic. Plaintiffs allege a hodgepodge of claims, 
20 none of them viable, all in an attempt to undermine Defendantsโ effort to protect Nevada voters 
21 during an unprecedented public health crisis. In so doing, they pose a clear and direct threat to 
22 Proposed Intervenorsโ rights and legal interests. 
23 For the reasons set forth below, Proposed Intervenors are entitled to intervene in this case 
24 as a matter of right under Rule 24(a)(2). Such intervention is needed to ensure not only the 
25 fairness of the June Primary, but also the substantial and distinct legal interests of Proposed 
26 Intervenors, which will otherwise be inadequately represented in the litigation. In the alternative, 
27 Proposed  Intervenors  should  be  granted  permissive  intervention  pursuant  to  Rule  24(b).  In 
28
2 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 27   Filed 04/27/20   Page 3 of 14
 
1 accordance with Rule 24(c), a proposed Answer is attached as Exhibit 2. Also attached as 
2 Exhibit 1 is Proposed Intervenorsโ brief in opposition to Plaintiffsโ motion for a preliminary 
3 injunction.1   
4 BACKGROUND 
5 In response to the unprecedented public health crisis dominating headlines and impacting 
6 daily lives across the globe, on March 24, 2020, the Secretary announced plans to โconduct an 
7 all-mail electionโ for the June Primary. Press Release, Nev. Secโy of State, Secretary Cegavske 
8 Announces Plan to Conduct the June 9, 2020 Primary Election by All Mail (Mar. 24, 2010), 
9 https://www.nvsos.gov/sos/Home/Components/News/News/2823/23; see also Complaint, ECF 
10 No. 1, ยถยถ 13โ18. In the weeks that followed, county officials, including the Washoe Registrar, 
11 released details of their respective plans implementing the all-mail election. See, e.g., Washoe 
12 Cty.  Registrar  of  Voters,  Notice  of  Vote-By-Mail  Election  of  Official  Sample  Ballot, 
13 https://www.washoecounty.us/voters/vote-by-mail/Vote-by-Mail-Notice.pdf  (last  visited  Apr. 
14 24, 2020); Clark Cty. Election Depโt, June 9, 2020, Primary Election Notice of All-Mail Ballot 
15 Election  (Apr.  15,  2020),  https://www.clarkcountynv.gov/election/Documents/2020/Mailer-
16 Notice-20P-EXPANDED.pdf; see also Complaint ยถยถ 19โ21. 
17 Concerned about various statutory and constitutional infirmities that threaten to restrict 
18 access to the franchise in the June Primary and beyond, NSDP, DNC, DCCC, and Priorities 
19 USA, joined by four Nevada voters (collectively, the โState Court Plaintiffsโ), filed a lawsuit in 
20 Nevada state court seeking declaratory and injunctive relief (the โState Court Actionโ) on April 
21 16, 2020. See Ex. 3. The complaint was followed by a motion for a preliminary injunction 
22 shortly  thereafter.  See  Ex.  4.  Significantly,  the  State  Court  Plaintiffs  โdo  not  object  to 
23
                                                 
24
1   While Proposed Intervenors believe, for the reasons discussed in their brief in opposition 
25
to Plaintiffsโ motion for a preliminary injunction, that Plaintiffsโ complaint should be dismissed 
in its entirety, they are including a proposed Answer to fully comply with the requirements of 
26
Rule 24(c). See Landryโs, Inc. v. Sandoval, No. 2:15-cv-00160-GMN-PAL, 2016 WL 1239254, 
at *3 (D. Nev. Mar. 28, 2016). 
27
28
3 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 27   Filed 04/27/20   Page 4 of 14
 
1 Defendantsโ expansion of vote by mail; indeed, the current public health crisis necessitates that 
2 states allow voters to cast ballots without leaving their homes.โ Ex. 3 ยถ 2; see also Ex. 4 at 3. 
3 Instead, they initiated the State Court Action โto ensure that all eligible Nevada voters have a fair 
4 opportunity to exercise their right to the franchise,โ which requires both vote by mail and 
5 meaningful opportunities for in-person voting. Ex. 3 ยถยถ 1โ6.2  
6 STANDARD OF LAW 
7 โRule  24  traditionally  receives  liberal  construction  in  favor  of  applicants  for 
8 intervention.โ Arkaki v. Cayetano, 324 F.3d 1078, 1083 (9th Cir. 2003); see also W. Expl. LLC v. 
9 U.S. Depโt of Interior, No. 3:15-cv-00491-MMD-VPC, 2016 WL 355122, at *2 (D. Nev. Jan. 28, 
10 2016) (noting Rule 24โs liberal construction and โfocus[] on practical considerations rather than 
11 technical distinctionsโ). 
12 The Ninth Circuit โrequire[s] applicants for intervention as of right pursuant to Rule 
13 24(a)(2) to meet a four-part testโ: 
14 (1) the  motion  must  be  timely;  (2) the  applicant  must  claim  a  โsignificantly 
protectableโ interest relating to the property or transaction which is the subject of 
15 the action; (3) the applicant must be so situated that the disposition of the action 
may as a practical matter impair or impede its ability to protect that interest; and 
16 (4) the applicantโs interest must be inadequately represented by the parties to the 
action. 
17  
 
18 United States v. Aerojet Gen. Corp., 606 F.3d 1142, 1148 (9th Cir. 2010) (quoting California ex 
19 rel. Lockyer v. United States, 450 F.3d 436, 440 (9th Cir. 2006)). 
20   โRule 24(b) permits the Court to allow anyone to intervene who submits a timely motion 
21 and โhas a claim or defense that shares with the main action a common question of law or fact.โโ 
22
                                                 
23
2   The State Court Plaintiffs primarily challenge four attributes of Nevadaโs election laws 
24
and procedures: the closure of all but one in-person polling location in each county for the June 
Primary, Ex. 3 ยถยถ 89โ113; the exclusion of inactive voters from Defendantsโ planned mailing of 
25
ballots for the June Primary, id. ยถยถ 114โ29; Nevadaโs Voter Assistance Ban, which prohibits 
anyone other than a voterโs family member from assisting with the return of a mail ballot, id. 
26
ยถยถ 135โ61; and the Ballot Rejection Rules, Defendantsโ policies for rejecting ballots due to 
missing or mismatched signatures on mail ballots, id. ยถยถ 162โ73. 
27
28
4 
 
 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 27   Filed 04/27/20   Page 5 of 14
 
1 Nevada v. United States, No. 3:18-cv-569-MMD-CBC, 2019 WL 718825, at *2 (D. Nev. Jan. 14, 
2 2019) (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(b)(1)(B)). In addition to a common question of law or fact, 
3 permissive  intervention  under  Rule  24(b)  also  requires  (1) a  timely  motion  and  (2) an 
4 independent basis for the courtโs jurisdiction. See Donnelly v. Glickman, 159 F.3d 405, 412 (9th 
5 Cir. 1998). 
6 ARGUMENT 
7 I.  Proposed Intervenors satisfy Rule 24(a)โs requirements for intervention as a matter 
of right. 
8
 
9   Proposed Intervenors satisfy each of the four requirements of Rule 24(a). 
10   First, the motion is timely. Plaintiffs filed their complaint on April 21, 2020; this motion 
11 follows six days later, and in advance of the deadline provided by the Court for Defendantsโ 
12 responses to Plaintiffsโ motions for a preliminary injunction and to consolidate. See ECF No. 14. 
13 There has therefore been no delay, and no possible risk of prejudice to the other parties. See 
14 League of United Latin Am. Citizens v. Wilson, 131 F.3d 1297, 1302 (9th Cir. 1997); see also 
15 Nevada, 2019 WL 718825, at *2 (granting motion to intervene filed several weeks after action 
16 commenced); W. Expl., 2016 WL 355122, at *2 (granting motion to intervene filed nearly two 
17 months after action commenced). 
18   Second and third, Proposed Intervenors have significant protectable interests in this 
19 lawsuit that might be impaired by Plaintiffsโ causes of action. โAn applicant [for intervention] 
20 has a โsignificant protectable interestโ in an action if (1) it asserts an interest that is protected 
21 under some law, and (2) there is a โrelationshipโ between its legally protected interest and the 
22 plaintiffโs claims.โ W. Expl., 2016 WL 355122, at *2 (quoting Lockyer, 450 F.3d at 441). In 
23 assessing whether such an interest is sufficiently โimpair[ed] or impede[d],โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 
24 24(a)(2), courts โlook[] to the โpractical consequencesโ of denying intervention.โ Nat. Res. Def. 
25 Council v. Costle, 561 F.2d 904, 909 (D.C. Cir. 1977) (quoting Nuesse v. Camp, 385 F.2d 694, 
26 702 (D.C. Cir. 1967)). 
27   Plaintiffsโ challenge to the all-mail June Primary compromises legally protected interests

1 for each of the Proposed Intervenors. If Plaintiffs succeed and Defendantsโ plans to mail ballots 
2 to registered voters are thwarted, then NSDP, DNC, DCCC, and Priorities USAโeach of which 
3 is an organization dedicated to promoting the franchise and ensuring the election of Democratic 
4 Party  candidatesโwill  suffer  direct  injury  because  fewer  Democratic  voters  will  have  an 
5 opportunity to vote in the June Primary. See Ex. 3 ยถยถ 14โ16. Without expansive options to vote 
6 by mail, many voters will be forced to choose between risking their health to vote in person and 
7 participating in the June primary, and the result will be far less robust voter turnout in the 
8 primary. Courts have routinely concluded that interference with a political partyโs electoral 
9 prospects constitutes a direct injury that satisfies Article III standing, which goes beyond the 
10 requirement needed for intervention under Rule 24(a)(2) in this case. See, e.g., Tex. Democratic 
11 Party v. Benkiser, 459 F.3d 582, 586โ87 (5th Cir. 2006) (recognizing that โharm to [] election

13 Husted, 189 F. Supp. 3d 708, 726 (S.D. Ohio 2016) (political party โestablished an injury in factโ

18 part, revโd in part on other grounds sub nom. League of Women Voters of N.C. v. North 
19 Carolina, 769 F.3d 224 (4th Cir. 2014); see also Town of Chester v. Laroe Estates, Inc., 137 S. 
20 Ct. 1645, 1651 (2017) (noting that an intervenor of right only needs โArticle III standing in order

3 nom. Democratic Natโl Comm. v. Hobbs, 948 F.3d 989 (9th Cir. 2020) (en banc). 
4   Proposed Intervenor John Solomon also has a distinct, legally protected interest in this

1  POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
2  I.  INTRODUCTION 
3  Little has changed since Plaintiffsโ first motion for a preliminary injunction. The 
4  relevant facts are as stated in the Courtโs order dated April 30, 2020.  See Paher v. 
5  Cegavske, ___ F. Supp.3d ___, 2020 WL 2089813, *2โ4 (D. Nev. 2020).  Plaintiffs did not 
6  seek reconsideration of the Courtโs April 30, 2020 order, as provided for by Rule 60(b) of 
7  the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Plaintiffs did not seek expedited appellate review 
8  premised on the irreparable harm associated with mail-in voting for the June 9, 2020 
9  primary, for which the counties have already mailed ballots.   
10  Instead, Plaintiffs waited two weeks to file an amended complaint that rehashes 
11  the original challenge to the legal and statutory basis for the decision by state and local 
  12  election officials to implement an all-mail primary election for June 9, 2020.  The second 
13  motion is a notably cumbersome read, 24 pages in total, because it simply repeats all of 
14  the legal arguments from the original motion, with a few new bells and whistles.  Simply 
15  stated, it a retread, and yet it comes a full two weeks after the Courtโs decision on the 
16  first motion for preliminary injunction.  The inexplicable 2-week delay makes this Courtโs 
17  Purcell concerns from the April 30, 2020 order even more applicable than before, and 
18  further justifies the application of the equitable doctrine of laches.   
19  As a matter of law, Plaintiffsโ second motion for preliminary injunction specifically 
20  takes issue with the Courtโs conclusion that the Washoe County registrar appears to have 
21  satisfied the notice requirement of NRS ยง 293.213(5), even though notice was provided 
22  after the March deadlines described at NRS ยง 293.205 and .206. (ECF. No 65 at 4โ6). See 
23  Paher, 2020 WL 2089813, *10. Plaintiffs neglect to explain why this warrants a second 
24  motion given the Courtโs finding that the issue is rendered moot by Plaintiffsโ lack of 
25  standing.  See id.  Nothing argued by Plaintiffs suggests any new basis for standing here.   
26  From a factual standpoint, Plaintiffsโ second motion is likewise bereft of substance.   
27  Plaintiffs anxiously describe some new developments in Clark County: specifically the 
28  implementation  of  an  election  plan  that  โgives  voters  advantages  over  other-county 
-2- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 78   Filed 05/20/20   Page 3 of 11
1  voters, including by (i) sending absent ballots to inactive voters and, as reported, โallow a 
2  bipartisan group of deputized โfield registrarsโ to collect sealed ballots from voters.โ (ii) 
3  creating more vote centers than other Nevada counties.โ (ECF No. 64 at 2:12โ15).   By 
4  now  complaining  of  more  vote  centers  (which  presumably  allow  for  more  in-person 
5  voting), Plaintiffs contradict the rationale for their first motion.  While the first motion 
6  advanced  the  speculative proposition  that  less  in-person  voting  would  facilitate  voter 
7  fraud,  the  second  motion  expresses  concern  about  Clark  Countyโs  decision  to  expand 
8  opportunities for in-person voting.  If there is a hearing on this retread motion, Plaintiffs 
9  should explain their change in position on the merits of more in-person voting.    
10  As to Plaintiffsโ first point about inactive voters and field registrars, they fall back 
11  on the same speculative, unsupported allegations of vote dilution that this court has 
  12  already rejected.  Under Nevada law, Clark County election officials have the discretion 
13  to  determine  the  best  methods  of  reaching  voters  in  their  large,  populous,  and 
14  geographically diverse county.  Plaintiffs do not identify how the addition of vote centers, 
15  or the decision to mail ballots to inactive voters, runs afoul of Nevadaโs election statutes. 
16  Plaintiffsโ  demand  for  injunctive  relief  continues  to  be  grounded  in  their  unprovable 
17  assertion that vote-by-mail processes are inferior to in-person processes as a means of 
18  combatting voter fraud. No evidence has been provided warranting reconsideration of this 
19  courtโs prior order on this issue.   
20  This  is  ultimately  a  policy  argument  that  Plaintiffs  must  pursue  through 
21  legislative channels, not through civil rights litigation at this belated hour.  Injunctive 
22  relief remains unwarranted in this case.              
23  II.  STANDARD OF REVIEW1  
24  Rule 12(b)(1) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure allows defendants to seek 
25  dismissal of a claim or action for a lack of subject matter jurisdiction.  Dismissal under 
                                                 
26 
1 This section covers only the standard of review for dismissal under Rule 12(b)(1) 
27  of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.  The standard for issuance of a preliminary 
injunction is discussed in the Secretaryโs opposition to Plaintiffโs original motion for a 
28 
preliminary injunction. (ECF No. 28 at 3-4). In the interest of brevity, the discussion is 
not repeated here.   
-3- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 78   Filed 05/20/20   Page 4 of 11
1  Rule 12(b)(1) is appropriate if the complaint, considered in its entirety, fails to allege facts 
2  on its face that are sufficient to establish subject matter jurisdiction.  In re Dynamic 
3  Random Access Memory (DRAM) Antitrust Litigation, 546 F.3d 981, 984โ85 (9th Cir. 
4  2008). 
5  Although the defendant is the moving party in a motion to dismiss brought under 
6  Rule 12(b)(1), the plaintiff is the party invoking the courtโs jurisdiction.  As a result, the 
7  plaintiff bears the burden of proving that the case is properly in federal court.  McCauley 
8  v. Ford Motor Co., 264 F.3d 952, 957 (9th Cir. 2001) (citing McNutt v. General Motors 
9  Acceptance  Corp.,  298  U.S.  178,  189  (1936)).    Federal  courts  are  courts  of  limited 
10  jurisdiction. Owen Equip. & Erection Co. v. Kroger, 437 U.S. 365, 374 (1978).  A federal 
11  court  is  presumed  to  lack  jurisdiction  in  a  particular  case  unless  the  contrary 
  12  affirmatively appears.  Stock West, Inc. v. Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation, 
13  873 F.2d 1221, 1225 (9th Cir. 1989).  Thus, federal subject matter jurisdiction must exist 
14  at the time an action is commenced.  Mallard Auto. Grp., Ltd. v. United States, 343 F. 
15  Supp. 2d 949, 952 (D. Nev. 2004). 
16  Article III, ยง 2 of the U.S. Constitution states that the federal courts may only 
17  adjudicate โCasesโ and โControversiesโ.  See Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 
18  559 (1992).  The case-or-controversy requirement of Article III requires that Plaintiffs 
19  establish their โstandingโ as a jurisdictional prerequisite to the prosecution of this law 
20  suit.    Clapper  v.  Amnesty  International  USA,  586  U.S.  398,  408  (2013).    The  Court 
21  discussed the elements of standing in its decision of April 30, 2020.  See Paher, 2020 WL 
22  2089813, *4โ5.  
23  As the Court previously held, see Paher, 2020 WL 2089813, *5, Plaintiffs do not 
24  have standing to pursue allegations that their votes have been diluted in violation of 
25  rights guaranteed by the First and the Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution. 
26  At this early point in the election cycle, no votes have even been counted.  Until the votes 
27  have been counted and the 2020 primary election has run its course, it is impossible to 
28  know  whether  anyoneโs  vote  will  be  diluted.    Plaintiffs  speculate  that  the  election-
-4- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 78   Filed 05/20/20   Page 5 of 11
1  integrity  and  anti-fraud  measures  in  place  for  the  2020  primary  election  are  not 
2  sufficiently robust to prevent voter fraud.   Without evidence, Plaintiffs offer no reason 
3  why this Court should reconsider its prior order on the same legal issue in this case.   
4  Ultimately, the search for the proper balance between voter access and election-
5  integrity  considerations  is  a  matter  for  policy  makers,  not  federal  courts.    Plaintiffsโ 
6  amended complaint must be dismissed on the ground that the Court lacks subject matter 
7  jurisdiction over their claims.         
8  III.  ARGUMENT 
9  A. Plaintiffsโ New Factual Allegations Do Not Satisfy the Standing Requirement 
10  Plaintiffs continue to challenge the decisions that state and local elections officials 
11  have made in preparation for the June 9, 2020 primary election.  At this point, their 
  12  principal complaint concerns the decision by elections officials in Clark County to open 
13  two additional vote centers, mail ballots to inactive voters, and task certain elections 
14  officials with the responsibility of collecting paper ballots at locations other than the 
15  established vote centers.  These decisions, they claim, will create โa flood of ballotsโ in 
16  Clark County, presumably fraudulent, that will lead to Plaintiffsโ disenfranchisement.    
17  (ECF No.at 8โ10).  This argument is no less speculative than their previous argument 
18  that statewide vote-by-mail processes would cause their disenfranchisement.  
19  Plaintiffs  have  simply  modified their argument  slightly,  claiming  now  that  the 
20  conditions in Clark County will favor urban voters to the detriment of rural voters. (ECF 
21  No. 64 at 2:12โ15; ECF No. 65 at 22:1โ9).  Plaintiffs do not allege, however, that their 
22  ability to access the polls in Washoe County has been unconstitutionally impeded.  To the 
23  contrary, they express an eagerness to vote, and no reservations about their ability to 
24  access the polls.  (ECF No. 64 at 3โ4).  Insofar as their renewed motion and amended 
25  complaint are premised upon the alleged preferential treatment of Clark County voters, 
26  their grievance appears to be grounded in a desire to  reduce voter turnout in Clark 
27  County rather than increase voter turnout in Washoe County.  (ECF No. 65 at 22:1โ9). 
28  They cite not a single federal case that supports their argument for adopting measures on 
-5- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 78   Filed 05/20/20   Page 6 of 11
1  a statewide basis to equalize voter turnout between urban and rural areas in Nevada. 
2  Assuming that such equalization is desirable from a policy standpoint, Plaintiffs might 
3  perhaps explore the possibility of making the polls more accessible in the rural parts of 
4  the state. 
5  Indeed, Plaintiffsโ federal lawsuit is misguided and runs contrary to principles of 
6  federalism and separation of powers.  The discretionary decisions of an executive branch 
7  official, including an election official, must typically be challenged in state court through a 
8  petition for judicial review, as provided by NRS ยง 233B.130, or by way of writ proceedings 
9  when judicial review in not available under the Nevada Administrative Procedures Act. 
10  See NRS Chapter 34; Kay v. Nunez, 122 Nev. 1100, 146 P.3d 801 (2006) (โHere, Kay 
11  understandably challenged the district court's order through both a petition for judicial 
  12  review and a petition for a writ of mandamus. As the petition for judicial review was the 
13  proper  mechanism  .  .  .  Kay's  writ  petition  was  inappropriate.โ).    There  are  limited 
14  methods for challenging agency decisions, such as those at issue here, because โ[t]he 
15  courts  must  be  wary  not  to  tread  upon  the  prerogatives  of  other  departments  of 
16  government or to assume or utilize any undue powers.  Galloway v. Truesdell, 83 Nev. 13, 
17  31, 422 P.2d 237, 249 (1967).  โIf this is not done, the balance of powers will be disturbed 
18  and  that  cannot  be  tolerated  for  the  strength  of  our  system  of  government  and  the 
19  judiciary itself is based upon that theory.โ  Id.    
20  Proceedings to obtain a writ of mandamus would typically be the proper method for 
21  compelling the Secretary of State to issue an order to county clerks requiring that they 
22  establish no more than one vote center per county, mail ballots to active voters only, and 
23  refrain from using field registrars. NRS ยง 34.160 states that mandamus may be used โto 
24  compel the performance of an act which the law especially enjoins as a duty resulting 
25  from an office, trust or station.โ  But โ[m]andamus will not lie to control discretionary 
26  action, unless discretion is manifestly abused or is exercised arbitrarily or capriciously.โ 
27  Round Hill General Improvement District v. Newman, 97 Nev. 601, 603-04, 637 P.2d 534, 
28  536 (1981).  Moreover, โ[a]n agencyโs interpretation of a statute that it is authorized to 
-6- 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 78   Filed 05/20/20   Page 7 of 11
1  execute is entitled to deference โunless it conflicts with the constitution or other statutes, 
2  exceeds  the  agencyโs  powers,  or  is  otherwise  arbitrary  and  capricious.โโ  Nuleaf  CLV 
3  Dispensary, LLC v. State, Department of Health and Human Servs., 134 Nev. 129, 133, 
4  414 P.3d 305, 308 (2017). (quoting Cable v. State ex rel. Empโrs Ins. Co. of Nev., 122 Nev. 
5  120, 126, 127 P.3d 528, 532 (2006)). 
6  Here, NRS ยง 293.345(1) is silent as to whether ballots may be mailed to inactive 
7  voters as well as active voters.  The Secretary has deferred to the discretion of Clark 
8  County election officials regarding the decision to mail ballots to inactive voters.  This 
9  decision is entitled to deference because it was not arbitrary and capricious, nor did it 
10  exceed the powers granted to the Secretary of State pursuant to NRS ยง 293.247.   
11  The same is true of the Secretaryโs decision to give county clerks the discretion to 
  12  establish the appropriate number of polling locations and field registrars within their 
13  individual  counties, based  upon  fiscal  concerns,  staffing  and  training  challenges, and 
14  related  logistical  complications.    As  a  matter  of  state  law  over  which  the  Secretary 
15  ultimately has enforcement authority, the resource allocation decisions of local elections 
16  officials are not subject to review by the federal courts.  See Pennhurst State School & 
17  Hospital  v.  Halderman,  465  U.S.  89,  106  (1984)  (โ[T]he  principles  of  federalism that 
18  underlie the Eleventh Amendmentโ prohibit a federal court from granting โrelief against 
19  state officials on the basis of state law, whether prospective or retroactive.โ).      
20   With respect to alleged violations of federal law, the decisions in question are 
21  entitled to judicial deference under the Anderson-Burdick balancing test, as discussed in 
22  the Courtโs order of April 30, 2020.  See Paher, 2020 WL 2089813, *4โ5.  However, the 
23  Court need not repeat the Anderson-Burdick analysis from its prior decision because 
24  Plaintiffs have not alleged any new facts that would give them standing to pursue their 
25  claims under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 and the U.S. Constitution.2  In fact, their new allegations 
26
