5 
6  STANLEY WILLIAM PAHER, et al.,  Case No. 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC 
7  Plaintiffs,  ORDER 
v. 
8 
BARBARA CEGAVSKE, in her official 
9  capacity as Nevada Secretary of State, et 
al., 
10 
Defendants. 
11 
12  I. SUMMARY
13  Contending with the novel coronavirus disease (โCOVID-19โ) pandemic, Nevadaโs
14  Secretary of State Barbara Cegavske (the โSecretaryโ), in partnership with Nevadaโs 17 
15  county  election  officials,  developed  a  plan  to  implement  an  all-mail  election  for  the 
16  upcoming June 9, 2020 Nevada primary in order to diminish the spread of COVID-19 (the 
17  โPlanโ1). Relevantly, there are currently five states in the western United States that 
18  conduct elections entirely by mail: Oregon, Washington, Colorado, Utah, and Hawaii. 
19  Nevada also currently allows for mail-in voting in certain mailing precinctsโseparate from 
20  absent ballot precinctsโwith no reported incidents of election fraud. It is also undisputable 
21  that under NRS Chapter 293, the Nevada Legislature has vested the Secretary with 
22  authority to enact voting regulations and that the Secretary has pronounced the Plan to 
23  safeguard  the  health  and  safety  of  Nevada  voters  (and  the  larger  public)  during 
24  unprecedented times.  
25  ///
26  ///
27  1The Court adopts Plaintiffsโ reference to the Plan but recognizes that Plaintiffs 
challenge  only  the  expansion  of  voting  by  mail.  Intervenor-Defendants  have  filed  a 
28  separate action challenging other aspects of the Plan (ECF No. 27 at 3โ4) which are not 
at issue in this case.  

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 2 of 24
1  Plaintiffs William Paher, Gary Hamilton, and Terresa Monroe-Hamilton here sue 
2  the Secretary and Deanna SpikulaโRegistrar of Voters for Washoe County (โWashoe 
3  Registrarโ)โchiefly claiming that the Plan is not โchosenโ by Nevadaโs Legislature, and 
4  that an all-mail election strips voter-fraud-prevention safeguards and unconstitutionally 
5  violates Plaintiffsโ right to vote due to purported vote dilution. (ECF No. 1.) Upon these 
6  contentions and others, Plaintiffs seek a preliminary injunction to stop the Plan (โPI 
7  Motionโ).  
8  The Court finds that Plaintiffs have not established an injury particularized to them 
9  to confer standing. However, even if they can establish standing, Plaintiffsโ claims fail on 
10  the merits and the other relevant factors for preliminary injunctive relief counsel against 
11  the Court enjoining Defendants from implementing the all-mail election provisions of the 
12  Plan. The Court finds that Defendantsโ interests in protecting the health and safety of 
13  Nevadaโs voters and to safeguard the voting franchise in light of the COVID-19 pandemic 
14  far outweigh any burden on Plaintiffsโ right to vote, particularly when that burden is 
15  premised on a speculative claim of voter fraud resulting in dilution of votes. The Court will 
16  therefore deny the PI Motion.2  
17  II. BACKGROUND
18  The following facts are taken from the Verified Complaint and exhibits attached
19  thereto as well as the evidence submitted concerning the PI Motion. 
20  A. The Parties
21  This action stems from the decision to hold the all-mail primary (i.e., to implement
22  the Planโs mailing provisions), which was announced to the public on March 24, 2020. 
23  ///
24  ///
25 
2In addition to the PI Motion, the Court has considered Defendantsโ and Intervenor-
26  Defendantsโ oppositions (ECF Nos. 25 (Washoe Registrar), 27-1 (Defendant-Intervenors), 
28 (Secretary), and Plaintiffsโ reply (ECF No. 43). The Court has also deliberated the 
27  arguments  the  parties  presented  at  a  hearing  on  the  PI  Motion  on  April  29,  2020 
(โHearingโ). Because Plaintiffsโ reply was unresponsive to Intervenor-Defendantsโ brief, 
28  the Court provided Plaintiffs an additional opportunity for Plaintiffs to respond to those 
arguments at the Hearing.  
2 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 3 of 24
1  (ECF No. 1-1.) The Plan applies only to Nevadaโs June 9, 2020 primary election. (Id.) The 
2  parties are described as follows. 
3  Plaintiffs are all registered Nevada voters. (ECF No. 1.) Stanley resides in Reno, 
4  Nevada and typically participates in in-person early voting. (Id.) Terresa Monroe-Hamilton 
5  and Garry Hamilton (together, โHamiltonsโ) are married, recently moved to Nevada, and 
6  also reside in Reno. (Id.) The Hamiltons ordinarily vote early or in person on election day. 
7  They registered to vote online the day before filing this lawsuit. (Id.) 
8  The Secretary is the Chief Officer of Elections for the State of Nevada, see NRS ยง 
9  293.124. (Id.) The Washoe Registrar is responsible for implementing the stateโs election 
10  laws  in  Washoe  County.  (Id.)  The  Secretary  and  Washoe  Registrar  are  collectively 
11  referenced as Defendants, where not individually referenced.  
12  B. Impetus and Concerns that Led to the Plan
13  The decision to implement the Plan was made to โmaintain a high level of access
14  to the ballot, while protecting the safety of voters and poll workers[โwho belong to groups 
15  who are at high risks for severe illness from COVID-19โ].โ (ECF No. 1-1.) In decreeing 
16  the Plan, the Secretary wanted to โreassure voters in Nevada that their health and safety 
17  while  participating  in  voting  is  paramount  to  state  and  local  election  officials.โ  (Id.) 
18  Pertinently, the Secretary is quoted, stating: 
19  Because of the many uncertainties surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic, as 
well as the immediate need to begin preparations for the 2020 primary 
20  election, it became necessary for me to take action regarding how the 
election will be conducted. 
21 
22  She further states that she, along with Nevadaโs 17 county election officials, โjointlyโ 
23  determined that โthe best option for the primary election is to conduct an all-mail election.โ 
24  (Id.) The Secretaryโs announcement of the Plan emphasized that election officials are 
25  focused on also maintaining the integrity of the election: โthe high standard Nevada has 
26  set for ensuring the security, fairness, and accuracy of elections will still be met.โ (Id.) 
27  /// 
28  /// 
3 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 4 of 24
1  C. The New Details of the Plan and Maintained Election Safeguards
2  Under the Plan, all active registered voters will be mailed an absentee ballot (mail-
3  in ballot) for the primary election. If a voter is registered to vote at his or her current 
4  address, they need not take any further action to receive an absentee ballot. (E.g., ECF 
5  No. 1-3.)  If an individual is not registered or needs to update registration information (e.g., 
6  name, address, and party), they are required to do so. (Id.) To accommodate same-day 
7  registration  requirements  enacted  by  the  2019  Nevada  Legislature,  the  Plan  also 
8  establishes at least one physical polling place in each of Nevadaโs counties and in Carson 
9  City. (ECF No. 1-1.)  
10  The Plan otherwise maintains Nevadaโs election system and safeguards. (See ECF 
11  No. 21 (Decl. of Wayne Thorley, Deputy of Elections for the Secretary).) For example, 
12  NRS ยง 293.2725(1) requires first-time voters in Nevada to present identification and proof 
13  of  residency  before  being  allowed  to  vote,  whether  in  person  or  by  mail.  (Id.)  The 
14  requirements to present identification and proof of residency for first-time voters are 
15  waived pursuant to NRS ยง 293.2725(2)(b) if election officials are able to match the voterโs 
16  driverโs license number, ID card number or social security number with personal identifier 
17  on  file  with  the  Nevada  Department  of  Motor  Vehicle  (โDMVโ)  or  Social  Security 
18  Administration (โSSAโ). (Id.) 
19  When voter registration applicants register (1) by mail, (2) through the DMV by 
20  appearing in person or using the DMV's on-line system, or (3) via the Secretary of State's 
21  on-line system, the overwhelming majority of those applicants are positively matched to 
22  the personal identifiers on file with the DMV or the SSA. (Id.) The match is made through 
23  automated systems, which the Secretary finds to be highly reliable. (Id.) Voters who are 
24  positively matched to personal identifiers on file with the DMV or SSA are not required to 
25  present identification and proof of residency before voting, even if they are voting for the 
26  first time in Nevada. (Id.) They can simply vote in person or by mail without submitting to 
27  ///
28  ///
4 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 5 of 24
1  additional verification processes. (Id.) Voters who are not positively matched3 to personal 
2  identifiers  on  record  with  the  DMV  or  SSA  must  present  identification  and  proof  of 
3  residency before voting (referred to as โID required votersโ). (Id.) These ID required voters 
4  constitute less than 1% of all registered voters. (Id.) They have different ballot return 
5  envelopes than other voters with an envelope flap indicating that the voter must return a 
6  copy of the voterโs identification and proof of residency, without which their votes will not 
7  count. 
8  Penalties  against  fraudulent  votes are  provided  for  under, inter alia,  NRS  ยงยง 
9  293.313, 293.730(2), (3), and 293.840. 
10  D. Nevadaโs Election System Already Permits Mail-in Ballots in Mailing
Precincts
11 
12  Nevadaโs governing statutes provide for mailing precinctsโspecifically NRS ยงยง 
13  293.343 through 293.355. Through these provisions, the Nevada Legislature has given 
14  the Secretary and county clerks authority to mail ballots to registered voters rather than 
15  requiring voters to request those ballots through the absent ballot process. 
16  NRS  ยง  293.343  provides  that  โ[w]henever  the  county  clerk  has designated  a 
17  precinct as a mailing precinct, registered voters residing in that precinct may vote at any 
18  election regulated by this chapter in the manner provided in NRS [ยงยง] 293.345 to 293.355, 
19  inclusive.โ NRS ยง 293.343(2). Further, NRS ยง 293.213 gives the county clerk unilateral 
20  authority to designate a precinct as a mailing precinct if one of two conditions is met: (1) if 
21  fewer than 20 registered voters reside in that precinct, or (2) if fewer than 200 ballots were 
22  cast in the last general election. NRS ยง 293.213(1), (3). A county clerk may establish a 
23  mailing precinct that does not meet the requirements of NRS ยง 293.213(1)โ(3) โif the 
24  county clerk obtains prior approval from the Secretary of State.โ NRS ยง 293.213(4).  
25  Mailing  precincts,  as  opposed  to  absent  ballot  precincts,  have  been  used  in 
26  Nevadaโalbeit on a small scaleโfor many years. (ECF No. 21 at 3.) In recent Nevada 
27 
3The Deputy of Elections for the Nevada Secretary of State attests that the lack of 
28  a match is โalmost always because of a typographical or printing error in [the] application 
to register to vote.โ (ECF No. 21 at 2.)  
5 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 6 of 24
1  elections, a statistically significant numbers of ballots were cast by the voters in mailing 
2  precincts, providing a reasonable sample of ballots cast without incidents of election fraud. 
3  (Id.) The number of ballots that voters recently cast in mailing precincts are: 2018 General 
4  election (3,879); 2018 Primary election (2,273); 2016 General election (6,069); 2016 
5  Primary election (362); 2014 General election (4,288). (Id.) 
6  E. Lawsuit
7  Plaintiffs filed this lawsuit on April 21, 2020. The Verified Complaint asserts five
8  claims for relief, detailed infra, and requests declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent the 
9  Secretary and county administrators from implementing the Plan. (ECF No. 1 at 8โ13.) 
10  Plaintiffs  particularly  challenge  the  Planโs  expansion  of  mail-in  voting  or  in  their 
11  characterization, โ[t]he Plan would require the State to forego almost all in-person voting 
12  and instead conduct the Primary by mailed absent ballots.โ (ECF No. 1 at 9.) Plaintiffs 
13  contend  that  the  largely  all-mail  primary  circumvents  various  statutory  safeguards 
14  designed to protect against voter fraud, and that their votes will as a result be diluted by 
15  illegal votes. (E.g., id., at 2, 9, 12.) 
16  Along with the Verified Complaint, Plaintiffs filed the PI Motion, a motion to expedite 
17  briefing and hearing on the PI Motion, and a motion to consolidate the requested hearing 
18  on the PI Motion with hearing on the merits of Plaintiffsโ Verified Complaint (โConsolidation 
19  Motionโ). (ECF Nos. 1, 2, 3,4.) The Court granted the motion to expedite in part (ECF No. 
20  14) and later granted the Consolidation Motion under Fed. R. Civ. P. 65(a)(2) (ECF No.
21  36)4.  The  Court  further  granted  intervention  by  the  following  parties:  Nevada  State
22  Democratic Party (โNSDPโ), DNC Services Corporation/Democratic National Committee
23  (โDNCโ), DCCC, Priorities USA, and John Solomon (collectively, โIntervenor-Defendantsโ).
24  (ECF No. 39.)
25  ///
26  ///
27  4However, at the Hearing the Court determined that a resolution on the merits of 
the case should be deferred given the Secretaryโs position as to her right to assert 
28  Eleventh Amendment immunity. Such a deferral would not affect the partiesโ ability to seek 
interlocutory appeal. 
6 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 7 of 24
1  III. PI MOTION STANDARD
2  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 65 governs preliminary injunctions. โโAn injunction
3  is a matter of equitable discretionโ and is โan extraordinary remedy that may only be 
4  awarded upon a clear showing that the plaintiff is entitled to such relief.โโ Earth Island Inst. 
5  v. Carlton, 626 F.3d 462, 469 (9th Cir. 2010) (quoting Winter v. Nat. Res. Def. Council,
6  555 U.S. 7, 22, 32 (2008)). This relief is โnever awarded as of right.โ Alliance for the Wild
7  Rockies v. Cottrell (โAllianceโ), 623 F.3d 1127, 1131 (9th Cir. 2011). To qualify for a
8  preliminary injunction, a plaintiff must satisfy four requirements: (1) a likelihood of success
9  on the merits; (2) a likelihood of irreparable harm; (3) that the balance of equities favors
10  the plaintiff; and (4) that the injunction is in the public interest. See Winter, 555 U.S. at 20.
11  A plaintiff may also satisfy the first and third prongs by showing serious questions going
12  to the merits of the case and that a balancing of hardships tips sharply in plaintiffโs favor.
13  Alliance, 632  F.3d at  1135  (holding  that the  Ninth  Circuit's  โsliding  scaleโ  approach
14  continues to be valid following the Winter decision).
15  On the merits-success prong, โthe burdens at the preliminary injunction stage track 
16  the burdens at trial.โ Gonzales v. O Centro Espirita Beneficente Uniao do Vegetal, 546 
17  U.S. 418, 429 (2006); see also id. at 428 (citing Ashcroft v. ACLU, 542 U.S. 656, 666 
18  (2004).  
19  IV. DISCUSSION
20  Plaintiffsโ  claims are  that the  Plan:  (1)  violates the  right  to  vote  by  removing
21  safeguards against fraudulent votes that dilute votes, which they claim is a severe burden; 
22  (2) violates the right to vote for legislative representatives to establish the manner of
23  elections by substituting a scheme that replaces the Nevada Legislatureโs plan; (3) violates
24  the right to vote under the Purcell5 principle; (4) violates Plaintiffsโ right to have, and to
25  vote in, federal elections where the manner of election is chosen by the stateโs legislature;
26  and (5) violates the right to a republican form of government under the United States
27 
28  5Purcell v. Gonzalez, 549 U.S. 1 (2006) (per curiam). 
7 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 8 of 24
1  Constitution. (ECF No. 2 at 7โ20.)  Defendants and Intervenor-Defendants raise threshold 
2  issues about Plaintiffsโ claims that the Court will address before turning to the merits.6 
3  A. Standing
4  Both Defendants and Intervenor-Defendants argue that Plaintiffs lack standing to
5  assert their claims. (ECF No. 25 at 11โ16; ECF No. 28 at 8โ10; ECF No. 27-1 at 9โ11.) 
6  The Court agrees. 
7  โArticle  III  of  the  Constitution  limits  federal-court  jurisdiction  to  โCasesโ  and 
8  โControversies.โโ Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497, 516 (2007). โTo satisfy Article IIIโs 
9  standing requirements, a plaintiff must show (1) it has suffered an โinjury in factโ that is (a) 
10  concrete and particularized and (b) actual or imminent, not conjectural or hypothetical; (2) 
11  the injury is fairly traceable to the challenged action of the defendant; and (3) it is likely, 
12  as  opposed  to  merely  speculative,  that  the  injury  will  be  redressed  by  a  favorable 
13  decision.โ Friends of the Earth, Inc. v. Laidlaw Envtl. Servs. (TOC) Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 180-
14  81 (2000) (quoting Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560โ61 (1992)). The party 
15  invoking federal jurisdiction bears the burden of establishing these elements. FW/PBS, 
16  493 U.S. at 231.  Moreover, the party invoking standing also must show that it has standing 
17  for each type of relief sought. Summers v. Earth Island Inst., 555 U.S. 488, 493 (2009). 
18  Among other things, the Secretary argues that Plaintiffs lack standing because their 
19  alleged injury is speculative and at best Plaintiffs hint at a possible injury only in the first 
20  claim for voter dilution. (ECF No. 28 at 8โ10.) Washoe Registrar similarly argues that 
21  Plaintiffsโ injury is speculative, unsupported and not particularized. (ECF No. 25 at 11โ16.) 
22  Intervenor-Defendants make the same arguments, but more fully argue why Plaintiffs have 
23  not alleged an injury-in-fact. (ECF No. 27-1 at 9โ11.) Intervenor-Defendants contend, inter 
24  alia, that Plaintiffs do not allege an injury-in-fact because Plaintiffsโ โpurported injury is no 
25  ///
26 
6Intervenor-Defendants argue that this Court is barred by the Eleventh Amendment 
27  from deciding this actionโwhich they contend amounts to an action to enjoin state officials 
for alleged violations of state law. (ECF No. 27-1 at 8โ9.) Neither the Secretary nor the 
28  Washoe Registrar, who are the directly concerned parties, substantively argue the issue 
in briefing or at the Hearing. The Court will therefore not consider the issue here.  
8 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 9 of 24
1  different than that of any other voter in Nevada (or any other citizen who will be governed 
2  by the candidates elected through Nevadaโs elections, for that matter).โ (Id. at 10.) In 
3  briefing and at the Hearing, Plaintiffs counter that they have standing, in gist arguing that 
4  mail-in ballots are unlawful under state law, resulting in vote dilution, and that vote dilution 
5  from voter fraud results in disenfranchisement, and โdisenfranchisement is a severe 
6  burden that is personal to the person disenfranchised.โ (E.g., ECF No. 43 at 4, 7.)  
7  Plaintiffsโ argument is difficult to track and fails to even minimally meet the first 
8  standing prong. The theory of Plaintiffsโ case, and which is the only alleged injury driving 
9  all of their claims, is that the Plan will lead to an increase in illegal votes thereby harming 
10  them as rightful voters by diluting their vote. (See generally ECF No. 1.) But Plaintiffsโ 
11  purported injury of having their votes diluted due to ostensible election fraud may be 
12  conceivably raised by any Nevada voter. Such claimed injury therefore does not satisfy 
13  the requirement that Plaintiffs must state a concrete and particularized injury. See, e.g., 
14  Spokeo Inc. v. Robins, 136 S. Ct. 1540, 1548 (2016) (citation omitted) (providing, inter 
15  alia, that an injury must be โconcrete and particularizedโ); Lujan v. Defs. of Wildlife, 504 
16  U.S. 555, 573โ74 (1992) (explaining that U.S. Supreme Courtโs case law has โconsistently 
17  held that a plaintiff raising only a generally available grievance about governmentโ
18  claiming  only  harm  to  his  and  every  citizenโs  interest  in  proper  application  of  the 
19  Constitution and laws, and seeking relief that no more directly and tangibly benefits him 
20  than it does the public at largeโdoes not state an Article III case or controversyโ).  This is 
21  not a pioneering finding. Other courts have similarly found the absence of an injury-in-fact 
22  based on claimed vote dilution. See, e.g., Am. Civil Rights Union v. Martinez-Rivera, 166

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 20 of 24

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 21 of 24
1  4. Plaintiffsโ Third Claim
2  Plaintiffsโ third claim is that the Plan violates the right to vote under the Purcell 
3  principle. (ECF No. 2 at 16โ17.) It is not clear that this is even a cognizable claim, though 
4  Plaintiffsโ contention contains other defects that render the purported claim meritless, 
5  which the Court discusses. 
6  In Purcell, the Supreme Court vacated an order of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth 
7  Circuit enjoining operation of Arizona voter identification procedures. 549 U.S. at 2.  The 
8  Supreme Courtโs ultimate ruling to vacate the Ninth Circuitโs order resulted in the subject 
9  Arizona election proceeding โwithout an injunction.โ Id. at 6. 
10  The ruling district court had denied the plaintiffsโ request for an injunction to enjoin 
11  Arizonaโs voter identification requirements. Id. at 3. In ruling, the district court did not issue 
12  findings of facts or conclusions of law. Id.17 The plaintiffs appealed and the Ninth Circuit 
13  set forth a briefing schedule that would have closed two weeks after the election. Id. The 
14  circuit court ultimately issued a four-panel order, about a month before the election, 
15  enjoining  the  enforcement  of  the  Arizona  requirement  pending  disposition  after  full 
16  briefing. Id. The court โoffered no explanation or justificationโ for its decision in the order 
17  or upon a subsequent reconsideration. Id. 
18  The Supreme Courtโs decision to vacate the Ninth Circuitโs order emphasized the 
19  โimminence of the election and the inadequate time to resolve the factual disputesโ as well 
20  as the possibility that a courtโs order, or conflicting orders concerning election provisions, 
21  may result in voter confusion. Id. at 4โ6.18 The Court underscored that such possibility 
22  ///
23  ///
24  17The Court noted that โ[t]hese findings were important because resolution of legal 
questions in the Court of Appeals required evaluation of underlying factual issues.โ Purcell, 
25  549 U.S. at 3. 
26  18In vacating the circuit courtโs decision, the Court concluded that the Ninth Circuit 
failed to necessarily give deference to the district court, although recognizing that the 
27  district court had not yet made factual findings. Purcell, 549 U.S. at 5. The Court also found 
that the circuit courtโs decision failed to show that the โruling and findings of the District 
28  Court [were] incorrect.โ  Id. 
21 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 22 of 24
1  should caution courts in deciding whether to grant or deny an injunction as an election 
2  draws closer. Id. 
3  This Court finds, as argued by Defendants (ECF No. 25 at 21โ23, ECF No. 28 at 
4  11), Plaintiffsโ reliance on Purcell is wholly inapposite to Plaintiffsโ position and ultimate 
5  goal hereโfor the Court to issue an injunction.19 To be sure, Purcell does not appear to 
6  support the Court deciding the PI Motion. Nonetheless, the Court considers and rejects 
7  Plaintiffsโ specific contention that, as to courts, Purcell โapplies to state and local election 
8  administratorsโ because โelection-alerting actions pose the same riskโ as to both. (Id. at 
9  16; see also id. at 17.) Plaintiffs provide no support for treating courts and states the same 
10  under Purcell. Clearly, courts and states serve very different functions in our system of 
11  governance, including in relation to prescribing the rules that govern an election. It is 
12  obvious in this regard that the states ordinarily do what the courts cannotโprescribe voting 
13  regulations. The Secretary, acting on behalf of the State of Nevada, has done so here, 
14  and the Court finds the contention that Purcell prohibits the state doing so meritless. 
15  Accordingly, Plaintiffsโ third claim fails. 
16  In sum, the Court finds that Plaintiffs have not established the merits of any of their 
17  five claims raised in the Verified Complaint. 
18  C. Balancing of the Equities
19  The Court further finds that a balancing of the equities favors Defendants and
20  Intervenor-Defendants. 
21  โTo determine which way the balance of the hardships tips, a court must identify 
22  the possible harm caused by the preliminary injunction against the possibility of the harm 
23  caused by not issuing it.โ Univ. of Haw. Profโl Assembly v. Cayetano, 183 F.3d 1096, 1108 
24  ///
25  19Plaintiffs also reference the recent Supreme Court decision in Republican Nat'l 
Comm. v. Democratic Nat'l Comm. (โRNCโ), No. 19A1016, 2020 WL 1672702 (U.S. Apr. 
26  6, 2020). (ECF No. 2 at 16โ17.) In RNC, the Supreme Court relevantly stated: โThis Court 
has repeatedly emphasized that lower federal courts should ordinarily not alter the election 
27 
rules on the eve of an election.โ Id. at *1 (citing Purcell; Frank v. Walker, 574 U.S. 929 
(2014); and Veasey v. Perry, 574 U. S. __, 135 S. Ct. 9 (2014)). Thus, RNC is equally 
28 
unsupportive of Plaintiffsโ ultimate request for an injunction. 
22 

Case 3:20-cv-00243-MMD-WGC   Document 57   Filed 04/30/20   Page 23 of 24
1  (9th Cir. 1999). The Court must then weigh โthe hardships of each party against one 
2  another.โ Id. 
3  As indicated above, even accepting Plaintiffsโ purported harm to them of being 
4  disenfranchised  due  to  vote  dilution,  such  disenfranchisement  could  be,  even  more 
5  concretely, claimed in the absence of the Plan (and additionally by confusion that may 
6  result by the Court enjoining the Plan, and appealโwhich would surely follow). The Court 
7  therefore  concludes  that,  at  minimum,  the  Planโs  all-mail  election  implementation  to 
8  protect the public during a public health crisis tips the scale of equity in favor of Defendants 
9  and Intervenor-Defendants (i.e., against the issuance of an injunction). 
10  D. The Public Interest
11  โIn exercising their sound discretion, courts of equity should pay particular regard
12  for the public consequences in employing the extraordinary remedy of injunction.โ Winter, 
13  555 U.S. at 24. It is clear that as triggered by the uncertainties of COVID-19, the publicโs 
14  interests align with the Planโs all-mail election provisions. As provided above, an injunction 
15  precluding  Defendantsโ  use  of  mail  ballots  in  the  June  9,  2020  Primary  would  put 
16  Nevadans at risk and may result in the very type of confusion that Purcell cautions against. 
17  In short, the Court finds that Plaintiffs have not proven that they are entitled to have 
18  this Court enjoin the Planโs challenged provisions. 
19  V. CONCLUSION
20  The Court notes that the parties made several arguments and cited to several cases
21  not discussed above. The Court has reviewed these arguments and cases and determines 
22  that they do not warrant discussion as they do not affect the outcome of the issues before 
23  the Court. 
24  /// 
25  /// 
26  /// 
27  /// 
28  /// 
23

1  It is therefore ordered that Plaintiffsโ motion for preliminary injunction (ECF No. 2) 
2  is denied for the reasons provided herein.

25 19. In Washoe Countyโs notice, created on April 10, 2020, it details the Plan.Ex. C. Washoe

9 Nevada Election Law
10 22.  The Nevada Legislature has enacted detailed legislation governing how elections are to

24 Anti-Vote-fraud Safeguards

28 And an individual who registers at the Department of Motor vehicles, by mail, or by computer
6

1 must present valid identification and a document establishing residence. NRS.293.2725.4
2 31. For all in-person voters whose name appears on the roster of registered voters (or they
3 provide an affirmation that they are entitled to vote), the voter โstate his or her name to the elec-
4 tion board officer in charge of the roster,โ who โshall . . . [a]nnounce the name of the registered
5 voter,โ require a signature and then authenticate it or resolve any discrepancy. NRS 293.285. The
6 voter โmust sign his or her name in the roster or on a signature card when he or she applies to

8 case can watch the personโs demeanor and can see if the person is trying to duplicate a signature
9 from an exemplar or produces the signature spontaneously. There are some exceptions, but those
10 are the general rules, and they allow local poll workers and watchers to monitor who is voting
11 and deny voting and issue challenges if appropriateโas does in-person voting in general. 
12 32. The signature is then compared by an election board officer with the signature on file or
13 on approved identification cards, such as a driverโs license. Id. at (1)-(2). Records are checked to

mail if they provide the county clerk the same information required at the polling location. NRS

14 Claims for Relief
15 Count I
     The Plan violates the right to vote by removing safeguards against fraudulent votes that
16 dilute legal votes.
17 36. Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference all prior paragraphs of this Complaint and
18 the paragraphs below as though fully set forth herein.
19 37.  The federal right to vote is fundamental, Harper v. Va. State Bd. of Elections, 383 U.S.
20 663, 667 (1966), and well-established: โUndeniably the Constitution of the United States protects
21 the right of all qualified citizens to vote, in state as  well as in federal electionsโ and to have that
22 vote counted. Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 554 (1964). 
23 38. โThe right to vote can neither be denied outright, nor destroyed by alteration of ballots,
24 nor diluted by ballot-box stuffing.โ Id. at 555 (internal citations omitted). โAnd the right of suf-
25 frage can be denied by a debasement or dilution of the weight of a citizenโs vote just as effec-
26 tively as by  wholly prohibiting the free exercise of the franchise.โ Id.
27 39. The right to vote inheres in, and is protected by, the First and Fourteenth Amendments of
28 the U.S. Constitution.
8

Case 3:20-cv-00243   Document 1   Filed 04/21/20   Page 9 of 17
1
40.  Nevada also recognizes a right to vote: โAll [qualified voters] shall be entitled to vote for
2
all officers that now or hereafter may be elected by the people, and upon all questions submitted
3
to the electors at such election.โ Nev. Const. art 2, ยง 1. Article 1, ยงยง 8 and 9 of the Nevada Con-
4
stitution protect against violations of due process (including for โlibertyโ deprivation) and free
5
speech rights and provide protection for the right to vote, as does Article 4, ยง 21 safeguards equal
6
protection and so protects the right to vote from disparate treatment.
7
41. Both in-person and absentee ballot voting laws encompass safeguards that protect against
8
voter fraud. For in-person voting, among other protections see supra ยถยถ 31,33,34, a first-time
9
voter generally must appear in person with identification and proof of residence location. NRS
10
293.272(1). To obtain an absentee ballot, among other protections see supra ยถยถ 32-36, a voter

clerk.โ NRS 293.313. Yet, the Plan strips statutory protections by the Legislature to prevent such
13
fraud. 
14
42. Both the in-person voting and absentee voting demonstrate a statutory scheme that en-
15
sures multiple levels of verification before voting to guarantee the integrity of the voting process.
16
Voters casting fraudulent ballots face the threat of felony prosecution. All of these protections
17
and penalties are provided by the Legislature and may not be overruled and replaced by govern-
18
ment officials as in the Plan. 
19
43.  The Plan would require the State to forego almost all in-person voting and instead con-
20
duct the Primary by mailed absent ballots. An election conducted by mail ballot only, per the
21
Plan, would all but ensure an election replete with both ballot fraud.
22
44. The Plan violates the Votersโ right to vote by diluting their votes with illegal votes given
23
the removal of safeguards against illegal voting established by the Legislature. 
24
25 Count II
  The Plan violates the right to vote for legislative representatives to establish the manner of
26 elections by substituting a scheme that replaces the legislaturesโ plan.
27 45. Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference all prior paragraphs of this Complaint and
28 the paragraphs below as though fully set forth herein.
9

2 represent them and the Voters did not vote for the Secretary and County Administrators to repre-
3 sent them. Yet the manner of voting proposed here is to be decided by the Secretary and County
4 Administrators instead of the elected representatives in the Legislature. 
5 47.  While state and local officials face balloting, they are not elected to be representatives of
6 the People in the Legislature. That eliminates representation, representatives, and the right to
7 vote for representatives in the Legislature to decide the manner of elections. 
8 48. That right to vote is fundamental, Harper, 383 U.S. at 667, and protected by the First and
9 Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, as well as Article 2, ยง 1 of the Nevada Consti-
10 tution (โAll [qualified voters] shall be entitled to vote for all officers that now or hereafter may
11 be elected by the people, and upon all questions submitted to the electors at such election.โ), and
12 Article 1, ยงยง 8 and 9, which protect against violations of due process (including for โlibertyโ de-
13 privation) and free speech rights and so provide protection for the right to vote. โUndeniably the
14 Constitution of the United States protects the right of all qualified citizens to vote, in state as 
15 well as in federal electionsโ and to have that vote counted. Reynolds, 377 U.S. at 554.
16 49. The Plan would overrule and replace the representativesโ chosen manner of election, the
17 Votersโ votes for representatives who would decide the manner of elections is invalidated. That
18 violates the Votersโ right to vote.
19
Count III
20 The Plan violates the right to vote under the Purcell Principle.
21 50. Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference all prior paragraphs of this Complaint and
22 the paragraphs below as though fully set forth herein.
23 51. The Purcell Principle is anchored in the right to vote and its potential for debasement. 
24 Purcell, 549 U.S. 1, 4 (citing Reynolds, 377 U.S. at 555). The Court held in Purcell that  โ[c]ourt
25 orders affecting elections, especially conflicting orders, can themselves result in voter confusion
26 and consequent incentive to remain away from the polls. As an election draws closer, that risk
27 will increase.โ 549 U.S. at 4-5. 
28 52. The U.S. Supreme Court recently applied this principle in Republican National Commit-
10
